item.title: Chinese "Salt Typhoon" Hackers Exploit Exchange Vulnerabilities to Target Organizations
item.description:
The Chinese APT group Salt Typhoon has been targeting critical sectors worldwide. They are known for their sophisticated cyberespionage capabilities and use multiple backdoors and hacking tools to maintain persistent access while minimizing detection. The group exploits vulnerabilities like Microsoft Exchange's ProxyLogon, PowerShell downgrade attacks, and public cloud services. AttackIQ developed an assessment template that emulates Salt Typhoon’s tactics to evaluate security controls against these threats. Continuous validation of detection and prevention pipelines is essential for mitigating the risks posed by Salt Typhoon's espionage operations.

Reference

item.title: Red Canary Report Surfaces Sharp Increase in Cyberattacks Involving Identity
item.description:
Red Canary's analysis of 93,000 threats published this week found that cyberattacks seeking to compromise an identity increased by a factor of four in 2024. The most common result was the installation of info-stealer software used for exfiltration. Cybercriminals are shifting tactics and techniques to gain access to centralized systems through which they can steal data or distribute malware, making it clear that cybercriminals are becoming more sophisticated. The report also noted that 95% of those incidents occurred prior to Apple remediating a Gatekeeper bypass technique last September, compared to only 5% that occurred throughout the rest of the year.

Reference

item.title: Signal Messenger Misused for Targeted Attacks on Defense Industry Employees
item.description:
The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) has identified a surge in targeted cyberattacks targeting employees and members of the Defense Forces. These attacks involve the use of Signal messenger apps for malware distribution, specifically the DarkCrystal RAT, which is a remote access trojan capable of executing arbitrary commands, stealing sensitive data, and establishing persistent control over infected systems. §Attackers are using compromised Signal accounts to send phishing messages that appear as meeting reports. The campaign has been active since at least the summer of 2024, with recent lures focusing on unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), electronic warfare systems, and other military technologies. The use of popular messengers like Signal significantly expands the attack surface by creating uncontrolled channels for information exchange. This makes it challenging to detect threats using standard cyber protection tools. CERT-UA emphasizes the importance of vigilance and encourages users to report suspicious messages immediately. The agency also highlights the need for enhanced security measures to counter such sophisticated attacks. Recommendations for Enhanced Security include turning off automatic downloads of attachments, regularly checking linked devices, keeping software up-to-date, and enabling two-factor authentication.

Reference

item.title: WhatsApp fixed zero-day flaw used to deploy Paragon Graphite spyware
item.description:
WhatsApp fixed a zero-click, zero-day vulnerability exploited to install Paragon’s Graphite spyware on targeted individuals. The company addressed the issue in December without a client-side update and did not disclose the locations of the affected users. Meta discovered and dismantled a malware campaign targeting journalists and civil society members with Paragon's spyware (Graphite).

Reference

>

Reference

item.title: ClearFake’s New Widespread Variant: Increased Web3 Exploitation for Malware Delivery
item.description:
ClearFake is a malicious JavaScript framework that injects fake browser updates into compromised websites through Drive-by Downloads. It uses JavaScript injected into websites to download two additional payloads from the C2 server. The latest variant introduced EtherHiding and used smart contracts from the Binance Smart Chain to obtain the second payload. ClearFake's interactions with the blockchain include fetching a single malicious JavaScript from one Ethereum address, delivering loaders like Amadey, IDAT Loader, and HIjack Loader, and deploying infostealers such as Lumma and Stealc. The developer encrypted ClickFix HTML code and hosted it on Cloudflare Pages to evade detection. ClearFake uses the web3 library to interact with Binance Smart Chain's contracts, including a custom ABI for the contract.

Reference

item.title: Dragon ransomware threat assessment
item.description:
Researchers from SentinelOne reported on Dragon RaaS, a ransomware group that straddles the boundary between cyber activism and cybercrime. Also referred to as DragonRansom or Dragon Team, the group emerged in July 2024 as a splinter faction of Stormous, which itself is linked to a broader cybercriminal syndicate known as The Five Families—an alliance that includes ThreatSec, GhostSec, Blackforums, and SiegedSec. Its primary targets include entities in the United States, Israel, the United Kingdom, France, and Germany.

Reference

item.title: Windows Shortcut Exploit ZDI-CAN-25373 abused as zeroday in widespread APT campaigns
item.description:
Researchers from Trend Zero Day Initiative (ZDI) have identified nearly 1,000 malicious .lnk files leveraging ZDI-CAN-25373, a vulnerability that allows attackers to execute hidden malicious commands via crafted shortcut files. This flaw has been exploited in cyber espionage and data theft campaigns led by state-sponsored groups from North Korea, Iran, Russia, and China, affecting government, financial, telecommunications, defense, military, and energy sectors across North America, Europe, Asia, South America, and Australia.

ZDI researchers traced the use of ZDI-CAN-25373 across multiple cyber operations dating back to 2017, uncovering its widespread abuse by at least 11 state-sponsored APT groups. North Korean APT groups were found to be the most active exploiters of this vulnerability, with nearly half of the known state-sponsored attacks attributed to them. These groups demonstrated extensive cross-collaboration in techniques, tools, and infrastructure.

Reference

item.title: DCRat distribution campaign against defense-industrial base
item.description:
CERT-UA has reportedly observed a series of targeted cyberattacks against employees of Ukraine's defense-industrial complex and members of the Defense Forces. These attacks, tracked as UAC-0200, have been ongoing since mid-2024 and escalated in early 2025.

In March 2025, Signal Messenger was identified as a distribution channel for malicious archived messages, often disguised as meeting reports. To enhance credibility, attackers used previously compromised contacts to send messages. The archives typically included a PDF file along with DarkTortilla, a cryptor/loader designed to decrypt and execute Dark Crystal RAT (DCRAT) for remote control of infected systems.

item.title: Hackers Exploit ChatGPT with CVE-2024-27564, 10,000+ Attacks in a Week
item.description: In its latest research report, cybersecurity firm Veriti has spotted active exploitation of a vulnerability within “OpenAI’s ChatGPT infrastructure” but there is no evidence that OpenAI itself has been breached. This attack has a global impact, with the United States experiencing the highest concentration of attacks at 33%, followed by Germany and Thailand, each at 7%. Other affected regions include Indonesia, Colombia, and the United Kingdom.

item.title: Sneaky 2FA, a phishing tool marketed through Telegram
item.description: Sneaky 2FA, believed to be sold via the phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) business model, recently figured in an adversary-in-the-middle (AitM) attack targeting Microsoft 365 users. Marketed as Sneaky Log by a full-featured bot on Telegram, Sneaky 2FA reportedly used fake Microsoft authentication pages with automatically filled-in email address fields to add to its sense of authenticity.

item.title: Targeted OAuth redirection attacks exploit Microsoft 365 for credential theft and malware delivery
item.description:
Threat researchers at Proofpoint have detected two ongoing, highly targeted cyber campaigns that exploit OAuth redirection mechanisms in combination with brand impersonation. These campaigns are designed to facilitate Microsoft 365-themed credential phishing and distribute malware, ultimately leading to account takeovers (ATO). The campaigns highlight growing risks associated with OAuth-based attacks, which leverage legitimate authentication mechanisms to deceive users and gain unauthorized access.

Reference

item.title: Babuk ransomware group claimed to have hacked the French telecommunications company Orange
item.description:
On 16 March 2025, Babuk ransomware claimed responsibility for a cyberattack against Orange, a French multinational telecommunications company. The threat actor alleges to have exfiltrated 4.5 terabytes of sensitive data, including customer records, employee information, internal documents, and financial data. If verified, this breach could pose significant risks to Orange customers and employees. Cybernews researchers consider the claims credible based on a provided data sample.

Reference

item.title: Cybercriminals Exploit CSS to Bypass Spam Filters and Track Users
item.description: Cisco Talos researchers identified a new technique used by cybercriminals to bypass spam filters and track user behavior via email. Malicious actors are exploiting Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) properties to hide content from detection engines and fingerprint recipients' email clients. This method allows attackers to evade security measures and potentially direct users to phishing sites.

item.title: Microsoft Discovers StilachiRAT: A Sophisticated Remote Access Trojan
item.description: Microsoft has identified a new remote access trojan (RAT), dubbed StilachiRAT, that employs sophisticated evasion, persistence, and data exfiltration techniques. The malware can steal credentials, monitor clipboard activity, clone security tokens, and hijack active RDP sessions. Though its distribution remains limited, Microsoft has issued indicators of compromise (IOCs) and mitigation guidance to assist defenders.

item.title: CISA Rehires Fired Employees, Immediately Puts Them on Leave
item.description: CISA rehires fired employees immediately on administrative leave pending a court decision. The agency plans to place them on immediate leave pending the outcome of a federal judge's ruling. The agency is charged with protecting U.S. federal networks, but has been forced to remove 130 employees amid Trump and Musk's push for workforce cuts.

item.title: Third of UK Supply Chain Relies on “Chinese Military” Companies
item.description: UK companies with larger, complex digital supply chains are heavily reliant on firms linked to the Chinese military, while a study by Bitsight found that 29.1 different providers and 81.6 different products amount to a 10% larger attack surface for threat actors. Providers of digital products are often more exposed to security risks than their customers due to complex vendor relationships and larger attack surfaces.

item.title: Alleged Data Breach at Korea Aerospace Research Institute Sparks Major Investigation
item.description: The investigation into a suspected breach of South Korea's Nuri space launch vehicle project involves an employee named A, who is under scrutiny for violating unfair competition laws. Colleague B, who resigned and joined a private company, has also been investigated. Evidence suggests that A and B exchanged sensitive data via messenger.

item.title: Chinese Hackers Target European Diplomats with Malware
item.description: Chinese hackers targeted European diplomats with malware, and MirrorFace expanded its operations to target a European organization with a refreshed set of hacking tools. Researchers from Eset spotted the hacking group tracked as MirrorFace and Earth Kasha deploying a backdoor previously exclusively used by APT10. The backdoor is known as Anel, also tracked as Uppercut. MirrorFace's use of the backdoor caused Eset to reclassify the group as a subgroup of APT10. Researchers observed the group running a heavily customized AsyncRAT inside Windows Sandbox and abusing Visual Studio Code's remote tunnels for stealthy access.

item.title: British law requires platforms to take measures against illegal content
item.description: Online platforms in the United Kingdom should take measures to prevent users from being confronted with illegal content and must remove it as soon as possible if exposed. They are required to assess their risk analysis before 16 March and implement concrete measures or have a plan. Offcom advises them to assess file sharing services for CSAM and write management programmes to prevent the spread of CSAM fathers through their services.

item.title: European Cyber Report 2025: 137% more DDoS attacks than last year
item.description: Cyberattacks are now a significant risk for companies worldwide, with an alarming trend of increased DDoS attacks and shorter, more targeted, and more technically sophisticated attacks. Organizations that do not continuously evolve their security strategies face significant financial losses and long-term reputational damage. The Allianz Risk Barometer 2025 highlights the growing limitations of traditional DDoS defenses, emphasizing the need for more adaptive mitigation strategies. Link11 is a specialized global IT security provider that protects infrastructures and web applications from cyberattacks.

item.title: Popular GitHub Action Targeted in Supply Chain Attack
item.description: A popular GitHub Action called `tj-actions/changed-files` has been compromised in a supply chain attack targeting secrets associated with CI/CD. The incident started on March 14 and involved a threat actor modifying the code to execute a malicious Python script designed to dump CI/CD (continuous integration and continuous delivery) secrets to build logs. StepSecurity, a security company specializing in GitHub Actions, found no evidence of leaked secrets being exfiltrated. Software supply chain security firm Endor Labs has also tracked this incident and found no evidence that downstream open source libraries or containers have been impacted.

item.title: Hackers are exploiting Fortinet firewall bugs to plant ransomware
item.description: Security researchers have identified a group called "Mora_001" that exploits Fortinet firewall vulnerabilities to deploy a custom ransomware strain called "SuperBlack." The Mora_001 threat actor exhibits a distinct operational signature, which the firm claims has close ties to the LockBit ransomware gang. Hostetler from Arctic Wolf notes that Forescout's findings suggest hackers are targeting remaining organizations who were unable to apply the patch or harden their firewall configurations when the vulnerability was originally disclosed.

item.title: Chinese Chatbot DeepSeek used to develop keylogger and ransomware with little review
item.description: Tenable researchers found that Chinese Chatbot DeepSeek could develop keylogger and ransomware without review. The chatbot refused to write code for these purposes, insisting on using human assistance instead.

item.title: US leads global online fraud rates
item.description: A study by ZeroBounce identified the United States as the country most impacted by online fraud with a high risk score of 64.2%. The US has the highest fraud rate at 0.3% and incidents occur mostly online, with 83% happening through digital channels. France follows closely behind with a risk score of 54.8%, followed by the UK (risk score of 50.2%), Ireland (risk score of 41.2%), Denmark (risk score of 34.1), Luxembourg (risk score of 30.7), Austria (risk score of 26.0), Netherlands (risk score of 25.3), and the UK (risk score of 28.1%).

item.title: Head Mare and Twelve reportedly collaborating to attack Russian entities
item.description:
Analysts from Kaspersky identified a series of cyberattacks targeting Russian companies in September 2024, revealing a strong correlation between two hacktivist groups, Head Mare and Twelve (alias -=TWELVE=-). Analysis identified shared infrastructure, malware, and tactics between the two groups, suggesting a potential collaboration in their campaigns.

Formed in April 2023, Twelve historically targeted Russian entities. The group reportedly went silent for several months, but on mid-2024, the group appeared to have re-emerged. Head Mare is believed to be a hacktivist group that historically targeted Russian and Russia-aligned organizations, active since at least the end of 2023.

item.title: Phishing campaign impersonates Booking .com, delivers a suite of credential-stealing malware
item.description:
Starting in December 2024, leading up to some of the busiest travel days, Microsoft Threat Intelligence identified a phishing campaign that impersonates online travel agency Booking.com and targets organizations in the hospitality industry. The campaign uses a social engineering technique called ClickFix to deliver multiple credential-stealing malware in order to conduct financial fraud and theft. As of February 2025, this campaign is ongoing.

This phishing attack specifically targets individuals in hospitality organizations in North America, Oceania, South and Southeast Asia, and Northern, Southern, Eastern, and Western Europe, that are most likely to work with Booking.com, sending fake emails purporting to be coming from the agency.

item.title: Europe's telecoms sector under increased threat from cyber spies, warns Denmark
item.description:
Denmark’s cybersecurity agency published a threat assessment on Thursday warning of an increase in state-sponsored cyber espionage activities targeting the telecommunications sector in Europe.

It is the first public warning by a European government agency that suggests governments on the continent share the alarm of the United States over a Chinese spying campaign tracked as Salt Typhoon, although the Danish authorities did not explicitly mention Salt Typhoon or China.

item.title: Signal No Longer Cooperating with Ukraine to Tackle Russian Cyber Threats
item.description:
The encrypted messaging app Signal has ceased responding to Ukrainian law enforcement requests regarding Russian cyber threats, a senior Ukrainian official claimed, warning that this inaction is aiding Moscow’s intelligence operations.

According to Serhii Demediuk (deputy secretary of Ukraine’s National Security and Defense Council), Ukraine had previously communicated with Signal through an official channel to warn about the app’s abuse by Russian hackers. These attacks reportedly involve phishing campaigns and account takeovers, often targeting Ukrainian military and government personnel. While Signal previously responded to such concerns, Demediuk said this is no longer the case.

item.title: Over 400 IPs exploiting multiple SSRF vulnerabilities in coordinated cyberattack
item.description:
On March 9, 2025, GreyNoise started to observe a coordinated surge in Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) exploitation, with over 400 unique IP addresses actively targeting multiple SSRF vulnerabilities across various platforms. The United States, Germany, Singapore, India, Lithuania, Israel and Japan have been identified as the top countries experiencing SSRF exploitation attempts

ENISA has issued a Flash Report on the subject on 13.03.

Reference

item.title: A new Android spyware named 'KoSpy' is linked to North Korean threat actors who have infiltrated Google Play
item.description:
A new Android spyware named 'KoSpy' is linked to North Korean threat actors who have infiltrated Google Play and third-party app store APKPure through at least five malicious apps.

The spyware campaign primarily targets Korean and English-speaking users by disguising itself as file managers, security tools, and software updaters. The campaign was attributed to APT37.

Reference

item.title: Cybersecurity firm Dragos has revealed a prolonged cyberattack by the Chinese threat actor Volt Typhoon into the United States electric grid
item.description: State-sponsored Volt Typhoon hackers were poking around the Littleton Electric Light and Water Departments for at least 300 days before the FBI gave the utility a heads up. Dragos released a case study about the hack, which it blamed on Voltzite, a "sophisticated threat group...that overlaps with Volt Typhoon."

item.title: China-linked cyberespionage actor UNC3886 targets Juniper routers
item.description: On March 12, Mandiant reported that China-nexus group UNC3886 exploited Juniper Networks routers between mid-2023 and early 2024. The attackers deployed custom backdoors with active and passive capabilities, allowing long-term access while disabling logging mechanisms. This tactic enables persistent espionage and potential future disruptions to critical infrastructure.

item.title: Alleged TurkNet Data Breach Exposes 2.8 Million Records">
item.description: According to the post from DarkWebInformer, the compromised data includes user credentials, email addresses, and potentially financial information. TuirkNet didn't confirm the breach until the time of writing.

item.title: Sabotage, espionage, cyberattacks: Russia recruits Belgians and pays them in cryptocurrency
item.description: A VRT NWS investigative report reveals that pro-Russian groups are recruiting Belgians online to conduct espionage, spread disinformation, and carry out cyberattacks, often paying them in cryptocurrency. A journalist infiltrated a Telegram group of over 8,000 members, which had previously disrupted Belgian municipal and government websites. Assigned small propaganda and intelligence-gathering tasks, the journalist was offered cryptocurrency as a reward. The Belgian State Security warns of increasing use of "disposable agents," a tactic also observed in other NATO countries. The investigation was conducted in collaboration with multiple European media outlets.

item.title: [NEW victims identified] Salt Typhoon performs reconnaissance of telecom networks and government infrastructure
item.description: Between December 2024 and February 2025, security analysts identified new activity by the Chinese state-sponsored group Salt Typhoon targeting Cisco network devices worldwide for initial access. Investigations revealed Salt Typhoon’s infrastructure conducting reconnaissance on networks belonging to the Australian telecommunications provider Spirit Telecom and Myanmar’s MyTel, on mid-February 2025. The group was observed interacting with at least two MyTel devices running Wowza Streaming Engine Manager.

item.title: BADBOX 2.0, a complex, China-based operation that compromised off-brand devices
item.description: BADBOX 2.0 is an expanded and more sophisticated version of a China-based cyber operation that compromised over a million off-brand Android-powered devices, including TVs, smartphones, tablets, and car infotainment systems. Discovered by HUMAN’s Satori Threat Intelligence team, this botnet facilitated various fraud schemes such as ad fraud, credential theft, and DDoS attacks, often without users noticing. The malware came pre-installed on some devices, while others were infected through unofficial app downloads. Researchers suspect multiple threat actor groups collaborated in the operation.

item.title: CISA worker says 100-strong red team fired after DOGE cancelled contract
item.description: A penetration tester who worked at the US govt's CISA claims his 100-strong team was dismissed after Elon Musk's Trump-blessed DOGE unit cancelled a contract – and that more staff at the cybersecurity agency have also been let go. "DOGE cut our entire red team and all support roles — over 100 people impacted. The following Wednesday, DOGE cut a second CISA red team also doing mission-critical work. As a result, I and many other experienced red team operators are now seeking new opportunities."

item.title: Microsoft quantum breakthrough claims labelled 'unreliable' and 'essentially fraudulent'
item.description: Microsoft's claim of having made quantum computing breakthroughs has attracted strong criticism from scientists, but the software giant says it’s work is sound – and it will soon reveal data that proves it. The quantum claims were made in February when Microsoft announced its in-house boffins had created "the world’s first topoconductor, a breakthrough type of material which can observe and control Majorana particles to produce more reliable and scalable qubits, which are the building blocks for quantum computers."

item.title: X hit by massive cyberattack amid Dark Storm’s DDoS claims
item.description:
The Dark Storm hacktivist group claims to be behind DDoS attacks causing multiple X worldwide outages on Monday, leading the company to enable DDoS protections from Cloudflare.

While X owner Elon Musk did not specifically state that DDoS attacks were behind the outages, he did confirm that it was caused by a "massive cyberattack."

item.title: Researchers expose new polymorphic attack that clones browser extensions to steal credentials
item.description:
Cybersecurity researchers have demonstrated a novel technique that allows a malicious web browser extension to impersonate any installed add-on. The harvested credentials could then be abused by the threat actors to hijack online accounts and gain unauthorized access to sensitive personal and financial information. The attack affects all Chromium-based web browsers, including Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Brave, Opera, and others.

Reference

item.title: SideWinder APT Targets Maritime, Nuclear, and IT Sectors Across Asia, Middle East, and Africa
item.description:
Maritime and logistics companies in South and Southeast Asia, the Middle East, and Africa have become the target of an advanced persistent threat (APT) group dubbed SideWinder.

The attacks, observed by Kaspersky in 2024, spread across Bangladesh, Cambodia, Djibouti, Egypt, the United Arab Emirates, and Vietnam. Other targets of interest include nuclear power plants and nuclear energy infrastructure in South Asia and Africa, as well as telecommunication, consulting, IT service companies, real estate agencies, and hotels.

item.title: ANSSI's cybercrime report 2024
item.description: In line with previous years, ANSSI now estimates that attackers linked to the cybercriminal ecosystem or known to be linked to China and Russia constitute the three main threats to both the most critical information systems (IS) and the national ecosystem in a systemic manner.

item.title: Z-Pentest Alliance claimed to have unauthorized access to the water supply infrastructure in the Valencian Community of Spain
item.description: NoName057(16) has claimed responsibility for unauthorized access to the water supply infrastructure in the Valencian Community of Spain. The threat actor published these claims on their Telegram channel and included a video related to their alleged cyber attack.

item.title: Ministry of Internal Affairs Hospital in Krakow became the target of a cyberattack
item.description:
According to the Vice PM, cybersecurity agencies, including Poland’s Cyberspace Emergency Response Team (CERT Polska), e-Health Center, and Central Bureau for Combating Cybercrime, are gathering evidence and helping the healthcare facility resume normal operations. Law enforcers have coordinated efforts to identify the perpetrators of the attack.

Reference

item.title: Magic Hound registers new infrastructure tied to Arda PowerLess malware
item.description: Security researchers identified new infrastructure linked to the Iranian statesponsored threat group Magic Hound, registered between January and mid-February 2025. This infrastructure is highly likely connected to a cluster previously reported by Recorded Future in December 2024, which was associated with the PowerLess malware variant “Arda”. While this infrastructure appears to function as both command-and-control (C2) and malware dissemination for Magic Hound activity, no new malware samples have been identified at this time.

item.title: North Korean hackers cash out hundreds of millions from $1.5bn ByBit hack
item.description:
Hackers thought to be working for the North Korean regime have successfully converted at least $300m (£232m) of their record-breaking $1.5bn crypto heist to unrecoverable funds. The criminals, known as Lazarus Group, swiped the huge haul of digital tokens in a hack on crypto exchange ByBit two weeks ago.

Since then, it's been a cat-and-mouse game to track and block the hackers from successfully converting the crypto into usable cash. Experts say the infamous hacking team is working nearly 24 hours a day - potentially funnelling the money into the regime's military development.

item.title: Large-scale cryptocurrency miner campaign targets Russian users with SilentCryptoMiner
item.description:
Kaspersky researchers discovered a mass malware campaign spreading SilentCryptoMiner by disguising it as a tool to bypass internet restrictions. While investigating the increased use of Windows Packet Divert (WPD) tools by crooks to distribute malware under this pretense, the researchers spotted the campaign.

Reference

item.title: Reporting cyberattacks on critical infrastructure mandatory from 1 April
item.description: At its meeting on 7 March, the Swiss Federal Council introduced a reporting obligation for cyberattacks on critical infrastructure, which will come into force on 1 April. Operators of critical infrastructure will be required to report cyberattacks to the National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) within 24 hours of discovery. These reports will enable the NCSC to assist victims of cyberattacks and alert operators of critical infrastructure.

item.title: Vulnerable ESXi Servers exploited all over EU
item.description:
2,800 Vulnerable VMware ESXi Servers in Germany Exploited.

Over 900 VMware ESXi Servers in Netherlands Affected by Critical Vulnerability

Reference

item.title: Microsoft says malvertising campaign impacted 1 million PCs
item.description: In early December 2024, Microsoft Threat Intelligence detected a large-scale malvertising campaign that impacted nearly one million devices globally in an opportunistic attack to steal information. The attack originated from illegal streaming websites embedded with malvertising redirectors, leading to an intermediary website where the user was then redirected to GitHub and two other platforms. The campaign impacted a wide range of organizations and industries, including both consumer and enterprise devices, highlighting the indiscriminate nature of the attack.

item.title: Data breach at Japanese telecom giant NTT hits 18,000 companies
item.description: Japanese telecommunication services provider NTT Communications Corporation (NTT) is warning almost 18,000 corporate customers that their information was compromised during a cybersecurity incident.

item.title: EU ministers sign cybersecurity declaration in Warsaw
item.description: During the meeting, participants agreed that investing in Europe’s digital resilience must go hand in hand with establishing more effective coordination and incident response mechanisms at the EU level. To reaffirm their commitment to closer cooperation on cybersecurity, Council members unanimously adopted the Warsaw Call declaration.

item.title: ENISA NIS360 report
item.description: The NIS360 is a new ENISA product that assesses the maturity and criticality of sectors of high criticality under the NIS2 Directive, providing both a comparative overview and a more in-depth analysis of each sector. The NIS360 is designed to assist Member States and national authorities in identifying gaps and prioritising resources. Our analysis is based on data from national authorities with a horizontal or sectorial mandate, data from companies within the in-scope sectors, and insights from EU-level sources such as Eurostat.

item.title: Cyber-attack on flight tracking portal
item.description: Flightradar24 is a Swedish Internet-based service that shows real-time aircraft flight tracking information on a map. It includes flight tracking information, origins and destinations, flight numbers, aircraft types, positions, altitudes, headings and speeds.

item.title: Typosquatted Go packages delivering malware loader targeting Linux and macOS systems
item.description:
Security researchers at Socket have identified an ongoing malware campaign infiltrating the Go ecosystem using typosquatted packages. The campaign introduces malicious loader malware targeting Linux and macOS systems, with at least 7 fraudulent packages impersonating widely used Go libraries. One of these packages appears to specifically target developers in the financial sector.

The malicious packages have been found using consistent obfuscation techniques and repeated filenames, indicating a well-organized threat actor capable of rapidly adjusting their tactics. These packages remain available on the Go Module Mirror, and Socket has requested their removal while reporting the associated GitHub repositories and user accounts.

item.title: FOG ransomware group has leaked source code of 19 new victims
item.description: Fog ransomware has leaked the source code of 19 new victims, many of them located in the EU. Also included EUMETSTAT, Europe's meteorological satellite agency, based in Darmstadt, Germany.

item.title: US charges 12 Chinese hackers in major government-backed espionage campaign
item.description:
US authorities have announced criminal charges against 12 Chinese nationals allegedly involved in a long-running cyber-espionage campaign tied to China’s government.

According to court documents, among those charged are two officers from China’s Ministry of Public Security (MPS), while the remaining ten worked for Anxun Information Technology, commonly known as i-Soon, a private firm allegedly connected to China’s APT27 hacking group, also called Silk Typhoon.

item.title: Over Half of Organizations Report Serious OT Security Incidents
item.description: More than half of global organizations have suffered an operational technology (OT) incident over the past 12 months, according to the SANS Institute. A particular concern is that “IT compromise” (58%) was cited as the most common OT attack vector, indicating the converged nature of the two historically siloed functions. Yet despite this, only 27% of budget decisions are led by CISOs.

item.title: Russian telecom Beeline facing disruptions after cyberattack
item.description: Cybersecurity media outlet The Record informs that the Russian telecommunications company Beeline faced a Distributed-Denial-of-Service (DDoS) that disrupted internet services for many users in Russia. Beeline, which serves over 44 million subscribers, confirmed the incident following reports from outage-tracking platforms and customer complaints. According to Downdetector, most disruptions affected Beeline’s mobile application, while some users also experienced website outages, notification failures, and general internet connectivity issues.

item.title: North Korean Fake IT Workers Pose as Blockchain Developers on GitHub
item.description: A network of North Korean fake IT workers has been creating personas on GitHub to obtain remote engineering and full-stack blockchain developer positions in the US and Japan, threat monitoring firm Nisos warns. The GitHub personas, which are reusing matured GitHub accounts and portfolio content, claim to be in Asia, and some of them appear to be employed at small companies.

item.title: Hackers exploiting vulnerabilities faster than organizations can patch
item.description: A cybersecurity firm's latest threat landscape report highlights an increasing urgency for organizations to strengthen their defenses. Hackers are now exploiting new vulnerabilities almost immediately, outpacing the time it takes most businesses to apply security patches. The report also points to a significant rise in IoT attacks, while other threats like malware and cryptojacking have seen some decline. Business email compromise has become a dominant cyber threat, with a sharp increase in incidents, particularly targeting corporate users. In healthcare, ransomware remains the most pressing issue, driving nearly all major breaches. Additionally, attackers are leveraging AI and more precise targeting strategies to exploit small- and medium-sized enterprises.

item.title: Silk Typhoon targeting IT supply chain
item.description: Microsoft Threat Intelligence identified a shift in tactics by Silk Typhoon, a Chinese espionage group, now targeting common IT solutions like remote management tools and cloud applications to gain initial access. While they haven’t been observed directly targeting Microsoft cloud services, they do exploit unpatched applications that allow them to elevate their access in targeted organizations and conduct further malicious activities. After successfully compromising a victim, Silk Typhoon uses the stolen keys and credentials to infiltrate customer networks where they can then abuse a variety of deployed applications, including Microsoft services and others, to achieve their espionage objectives. Our latest blog explains how Microsoft security solutions detect these threats and offers mitigation guidance, aiming to raise awareness and strengthen defenses against Silk Typhoon’s activities.

item.title: Outage of Dutch government authentication system DigiD
item.description:
On 3 March 2025, a series of distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks caused an outage of DigiD, the Netherlands' government authentication system. The attack reportedly affected several digital government services as it was not possible to log in to several websites where DigiD is used as an authentication method. These include, for example, municipal government websites, health insurers, pension funds and the Tax and Customs Administration. MijnOverheid, the platform for citizens to access government correspondence and personal records, was also impacted by the outage.

Reference

item.title: Nearly 12.000 API keys and passwords exposed in AI training dataset
item.description: On February 27, researchers at Truffle Security, the company behind the TruffleHog open-source scanner for sensitive data, discovered nearly 12.000 valid API keys and passwords in the Common Crawl dataset, which is used to train various AI models. The exposed secrets included AWS and MailChimp API keys, raising concerns about insecure coding practices influencing AI behaviour despite pre-processing efforts to remove sensitive information.

item.title: A newly discovered ClickFix phishing campaign deploys Havoc C2 via Microsoft Sharepoint
item.description: A newly uncovered ClickFix phishing campaign is tricking victims into executing malicious PowerShell commands that deploy the Havok post-exploitation framework for remote access. Discovered by Fortinet’s FortiGuard Labs, the campaign delivers phishing emails with fake OneDrive error messages, urging users to run a copied PowerShell command. This command downloads a secondary script from a SharePoint server, which checks for sandbox environments, installs Python if needed, and then deploys Havok as an injected DLL. The malware communicates through Microsoft’s Graph API, disguising malicious activity within legitimate cloud traffic. ClickFix attacks are growing in popularity, with cybercriminals using similar tactics across phishing emails and social media platforms to spread various malware strains.

item.title: Suspected Iranian Hackers Used Compromised Indian Firm's Email to Target U.A.E. Aviation Sector
item.description: A newly discovered phishing campaign, attributed to an emerging group tracked as UNK_CraftyCamel, has targeted fewer than five aviation and satellite communications entities in the UAE using a previously undocumented Golang backdoor called Sosano. Detected in October 2024 by Proofpoint, the attack exploited a compromised email account from the Indian company INDIC Electronics to send phishing emails with malicious ZIP attachments. These contained polyglot files and disguised shortcuts to execute Sosano, which enables attackers to execute shell commands, manipulate directories, and download additional payloads. Researchers suspect Iranian-aligned actors, possibly linked to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC), given the campaign's strategic focus on critical infrastructure.

item.title: Massive GitHub Malware Campaign Targets Gamers and Software Pirates with Redox Stealer
item.description: A newly discovered malware campaign is exploiting GitHub to distribute Redox Stealer, an information-stealing malware targeting gamers, software pirates, and modding enthusiasts. Cybercriminals have created thousands of fake repositories offering mods, game cheats, and cracked software for popular titles like Roblox, Fortnite, and Photoshop. Once downloaded and executed, Redox Stealer silently collects sensitive data, including banking credentials, cryptocurrency wallets, and gaming accounts, exfiltrating it to Discord servers for cybercriminals to exploit. Attackers use SEO poisoning, AI-generated content, and obfuscation techniques to evade detection, overwhelming GitHub’s security measures as new repositories are continuously created and re-uploaded.

item.title: USA - Russia cyber relations
item.description:
On February 28, The Record reported that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered US Cyber Command to halt all planning against Russia, including offensive cyber operations. This directive, issued to Cyber Command chief General Timothy Haugh, does not affect the National Security Agency's intelligence activities targeting Russia. The move aligns with the administration's efforts to normalise relations with Moscow.

On February 28, The Guardian reported that the Trump administration is downplaying Russia's cyber threat, diverging from longstanding intelligence assessments. This shift was evident when State Department official Liesyl Franz named China and Iran as cyber threats but omitted Russia. Additionally, the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has reportedly been directed to deprioritise reporting on Russian cyber threats.

item.title: CERT-EU Cyber brief - February 2025
item.description:
In the brief the reader will find the analysis based on 433 Open Source reports.

Policy, cooperation, and law enforcement. The EU aims to strengthen the EU's response to large-scale cyber incidents, Sweden and the UK seek backdoor access to private companies, and a former Polish Justice Minister arrested in Pegasus spyware case. Moreover, the US stands down on cyber Russia planning, Japan approves Cyber Defence Bill to counter sophisticated threats, Australian government bans Kaspersky products from government systems, and several police operations result in the arrest of cybercriminals.

Cyberespionage. China-linked threat actors compromised Belgian Secret Service e-mail exchanges, as well as telecommunications worldwide. Russia-linked threat actor Sandworm was active in targeting critical infrastructure in Europe. Multiple Russian threat actors targeted Microsoft device code authentication and Signal Messenger in multiple sectors, including defence. Pegasus software infected at least one EU government official, while another Israeli spyware targeted EU civil society, and North Korea continues targeting developers.

Cybercrime. The Belgian Port of Ostend was a victim of a cyberattack, China-linked threat actors were active in cybercrime worldwide, as were North Korea-linked Lazarus group, who namely carried out what is considered the largest cryptocurrency theft in history.

Information operations. China-linked Spamouflage operation targets the Spanish government, and a report analysed the impact of AI-driven disinformation in financial destabilisation. OpenAI removed accounts from China and North Korea that misused ChatGPT for malicious activities.

Data exposure and leaks. Orange group was a victim of a hack-and-leak attack in Romania, as was the Bulgarian Supreme Administrative Court.

item.title: Cybersecurity incident at Polish Space Agency (POLSA)
item.description: According to the official Twitter account, there has been a cybersecurity incident at POLSA. The relevant services and institutions have been informed. The situation is being analyzed. In order to secure data after the hack, the POLSA network was immediately disconnected from the Internet. We will keep you updated.

item.title: Vodafone Trials Quantum-Safe Tech to Protect Smartphone Browsing
item.description: Vodafone is trialing new quantum-safe technology using IBM Quantum Safe solutions to protect smartphone users from future quantum-enabled cyber threats. The proof of concept, supported by Akamai, will be tested on Vodafone’s Secure Net service, which safeguards users against phishing, malware, and identity theft. The initiative integrates post-quantum cryptography (PQC) standards to strengthen encryption, addressing concerns that quantum computing could eventually break current cryptographic protections. Vodafone and IBM, both founding members of the GSMA Post-Quantum Telco Network Taskforce, aim to establish a roadmap for implementing quantum-safe security across the telecom industry.

item.title: Palo Alto Networks provides AI-powered security to 5G enterprise customers
item.description: Palo Alto Networks has introduced Prisma SASE 5G, a cloud-native zero trust security solution designed to protect enterprise 5G networks from evolving cyber threats. The platform leverages AI-powered threat detection, SIM-based authentication, and secure access controls to defend against zero-day attacks and malicious malware. To strengthen its private 5G security offerings, Palo Alto Networks has expanded partnerships with industry leaders, including Nokia, NTT DATA, and NVIDIA, integrating its next-generation firewalls with advanced networking and AI solutions. As 5G adoption grows, this initiative aims to provide enterprises with seamless security across IT, OT, and mobile networks, addressing the increasing risks posed by AI-driven cyberattacks.

item.title: China-linked threat actors compromised Belgian Secret Service e-mail exchanges
item.description:
On February 26, the newspaper Le Soir revealed that Chinese threat actors compromised the Belgian Secret Service (VSSE) e-mail exchanges between 2021 and 2023. The threat actors exploited a vulnerability in the e-mail system of a US software supplier, called Barracuda, that was previously reported in 2023 and was being used by Belgian intelligence as well as the Belgian Pipeline Organisation, which monitors pipelines in the North Sea.

ENISA has issued a Flash Report on this subject on 27 Feb.

item.title: Hacktivist group Dark Storm targets ENISA’s website
item.description: On February 27, 2025, hacktivist group Dark Storm claimed a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack targeting ENISA’s website on their Telegram channel. ENISA’s website is up and active and did not suffer service disruption.

item.title: FBI confirms Lazarus hackers were behind $1.5B Bybit crypto heist
item.description:
FBI has confirmed that North Korean hackers stole $1.5 billion from cryptocurrency exchange Bybit on Friday in the largest crypto heist recorded until now.

The state-sponsored hacking group (tracked as TraderTraitor, Lazarus Group, and APT38) intercepted a scheduled transfer of funds from one of Bybit's cold wallets into a hot wallet, subsequently redirecting the cryptocurrency to a blockchain address under their control.

item.title: UK Delays Plans for AI Regulation
item.description:
The British Labour Government has reportedly delayed plans to put forward a draft bill on artificial intelligence over concerns that binding AI regulation could stifle the country's AI growth potential.

The United Kingdom, like the United States, has so far taken a decentralized approach to AI governance by trusting to existing statutes surrounding data, consumer protection, and product safety to do the work of protecting the populace.

item.title: Threat actor leaks Orange Group information from Romania
item.description: On February 25, a threat actor alleged to have stolen almost 6.5GB of data from Orange Group, specifically from Orange Romania. The leak mainly affects employees, partners, and contractors, as well as some customers. The data contains email addresses, source code, invoices, contracts, customer and employee information. However, according to BleepingComputer who analysed some of the leaked information, most of it seems to be outdated or expired. ENISA has issued a flash report about this incident.

item.title: Taiwan detains Togolese-flagged Chinese-crewed cargo ship investigating undersea cable damage
item.description: Taiwan's coastguard has detained a cargo ship along with its Chinese crew following damage to an undersea communications cable in the Taiwan Strait on Tuesday. Officials have not ruled out the possibility that this was a deliberate "grey zone" operation, a term used to describe acts of interference that fall short of open conflict.

item.title: Cyberattack targets Russian IT service provider LANIT Group
item.description: Russia’s National Coordination Center for Computer Incidents (NKTsKI) reported that LANIT, a major Russian IT service provider, experienced a cyberattack on February 21, 2025. The breach affected LANIT’s subsidiaries, LLC LANTER and LLC LAN ATM Service, which specialize in software development for ATMs and payment systems. NKTsKI has not disclosed the initial attack vector, the identity of the threat actor(s), or whether any data was compromised.

item.title: Signal will withdraw from Sweden if encryption-busting laws take effect
item.description: Signal CEO Meredith Whittaker has reaffirmed that the company will exit any country that mandates law enforcement access to encrypted user data, as Sweden considers legislation that could require messaging platforms to implement encryption backdoors by 2026. In an interview with Swedish media, Whittaker emphasized that end-to-end encryption (E2EE) cannot be selectively weakened, stating that any backdoor would compromise security for all users. This stance mirrors Signal’s previous threats to leave the UK over its Online Safety Bill, which included a controversial encryption-breaking clause. Sweden’s proposed law would extend telecom data retention rules to encrypted messaging apps, requiring them to store and decrypt messages for law enforcement—a move critics argue would undermine privacy and cybersecurity.

item.title: Have I Been Pwned Reports Huge Data Leak, Adds 284 Million Stolen Accounts
item.description: Cybersecurity service Have I Been Pwned (HIBP) has disclosed one of the largest data exposure events in its 11-year history, integrating 23 billion rows of stolen credentials from a malware operation dubbed “ALIEN TXTBASE.” The breach corpus contains 493 million unique website-email pairs tied to 284 million unique email addresses, alongside 244 million new passwords added to HIBP’s Pwned Passwords database.

item.title: Ransomware Attacks Focus on Data Exfiltration Over Encryption
item.description: A report by the American cybersecurity firm ReliaQuest reveals that more malware-spreading gangs are targeting data exfiltration. This method is faster, often taking just 48 to 90 minutes, and carries a lower risk of being traced by law enforcement. In contrast, when encryption is used, victims may refuse to comply with ransom demands and contact authorities, complicating the criminals’ plans.

item.title: UAC-0212 targeting Ukrainian critical infrastructure and supply chain
item.description: The Ukrainian Governmental Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-UA) has reported about an ongoing cyber campaign targeting enterprises in Ukraine’s energy, water, and heating supply sectors. Initially tracked in early 2024 under UAC-0133, the campaign has been attributed with high confidence to UAC-0002, a group associated with Sandworm (APT44, Seashell Blizzard). These operations have evolved in the second half of 2024, incorporating new tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), with attackers leveraging phishing lures and software vulnerabilities to compromise target environments.

item.title: Apple removes Advanced Data Protection in UK amid government demands
item.description: On February 21, Apple announced the discontinuation of its Advanced Data Protection (ADP) feature for new users in the UK, with plans to require existing users to disable it in the near future. This decision follows demands from UK security services for backdoor access to encrypted iCloud backups. Despite this change, services such as iMessage, FaceTime, Health data, and iCloud Keychain will continue to have end-to-end encryption in the UK.

item.title: OpenAI Purges ChatGPT Accounts: China and North Korea Weaponizing AI for Propaganda
item.description: OpenAI has confirmed that it is blocking accounts linked to Chinese and North Korean users who were using ChatGPT to monitor and influence social media discourse. These accounts were reportedly tracking anti-China sentiment, enhancing speech-monitoring tools, and generating fabricated news content aimed at tarnishing the U.S. and promoting pro-Beijing narratives, particularly in Latin America. Some were also linked to financial fraud schemes in Cambodia. OpenAI previously identified similar disinformation campaigns involving actors from China, Russia, Iran, and Israel, highlighting growing concerns over AI’s role in online influence operations.

item.title: Dragos's 8th Annual OT Cybersecurity Year in Review Is Now Available
item.description: The 8th Annual OT Cybersecurity Year in Review report from Dragos highlights escalating threats against operational technology (OT) and industrial control systems (ICS). In 2024, industrial ransomware attacks surged by 87%, with adversaries increasingly targeting critical sectors such as energy, manufacturing, and defense. The report introduces two new threat groups, BAUXITE and GRAPHITE, alongside continued activity from groups like VOLTZITE and ELECTRUM. New ICS malware, Fuxnet and FrostyGoop, disrupted infrastructure in Russia and Ukraine, respectively. The findings emphasize persistent security gaps in OT environments, including poor incident response planning, inadequate network segmentation, and insecure remote access. Dragos recommends adopting a risk-based vulnerability management approach and enhancing real-time OT monitoring to counter evolving cyber threats.

item.title: Cyber Blueprint - Draft Council Recommendation
item.description: The Cyber Blueprint should enable relevant Union-actors (meaning Union-level individual entities and networks of entities) to understand how to interact and make the best use of available mechanisms across the full crisis management lifecycle. It aims to explain what a cyber crisis is and what triggers a cyber crisis mechanism at Union level. It explains the use of available mechanisms like the Cybersecurity Emergency Mechanism, including the EU Cybersecurity Reserve, in preparing how to manage, respond to and recover from a crisis arising from a large-scale cybersecurity incident. It furthermore aims to foster a more structured cooperation between civilian and military actors, including cooperation with North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO), given that a large-scale cyber incident affecting Union civilian infrastructure on which the military rely may also activate NATO response mechanisms.

item.title: Iran Deploys AI - Guided Missiles & Drones
item.description: Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps (IRGC) recently tested AI-powered precision-guided missiles during military exercises in the Persian Gulf, marking a significant advancement in the country’s missile capabilities. The January drills in Bushehr and Khuzestan provinces focused on protecting critical infrastructure, including Iran’s nuclear and petrochemical facilities. Iranian officials claim the AI-driven missiles enhance targeting accuracy and overall performance, with new cruise missiles reportedly exceeding a 1,000 km range. While specific AI technologies remain undisclosed, the development raises concerns amid ongoing tensions between Iran and Israel, potentially impacting regional military dynamics.

item.title: Australia bans Kaspersky
item.description:
The Secretary of the Department of Home Affairs has today issued a mandatory Direction under the Protective Security Policy Framework (PSPF) to government entities to manage a protective security risk to the Commonwealth. This Direction requires Australian Government entities to prevent the installation of Kaspersky Lab, Inc. products and web services from all Australian Government systems and devices, and where found, to remove all existing instances.

Reference

item.title: North Korean APT-C-28 Expands Cyber Espionage Campaign
item.description: A recent report from 360 Threat Intelligence Center highlights the ongoing cyber espionage activities of North Korea-linked APT-C-28 (ScarCruft), also known as APT37 or Group123. Active since at least 2012, the group targets South Korea and other Asian nations, focusing on strategic industries such as aerospace, electronics, and healthcare. ScarCruft primarily relies on RokRat, a cloud-based remote access Trojan (RAT), delivered through spearphishing campaigns using malicious LNK shortcut files and fileless malware techniques. The group has evolved its tactics by shifting away from cloud-based command-and-control servers and embedding payloads directly into LNK files to evade detection.

item.title: Sticky Werewolf targets Russian and Belarusian organizations with LummaStealer
item.description: Researchers from Kaspersky published a campaign attributed to Sticky Werewolf APT group, informing that recent activity indicates a surge in attacks in January 2025, following previous operations observed in June 2024. The main objective of the group remains data theft, primarily through stealers and remote administration tools to establish full control over infected machines. Sticky Werewolf (alias Angry Likho), tracked since at least 2023, has traditionally focused on large organizations, government agencies, and their contractors. Based on fluent Russian-language bait files, researchers infer that the attackers are likely native Russian speakers.

item.title: Salt Typhoon campaigns targeting telecommunications analyzed
item.description:
Researchers from Cisco Talos have released an analysis on the widespread campaign targeting major U.S. telecommunications providers attributed to Salt Typhoon, believed to be a Chinese state-sponsored cyberespionage actor. Initially reported in late 2024 and later confirmed by the U.S. government, the campaign primarily involves persistent access to core networking infrastructure, extensive credential harvesting, and infrastructure pivoting.

According to the recent findings, Salt Typhoon has primarily gained access to Cisco networking devices using legitimate stolen credentials, rather than exploiting vulnerabilities. The only confirmed instance of vulnerability exploitation involved CVE-2018-0171, a known Cisco vulnerability. Other reported cases of vulnerability abuse, including CVE-2023-20198, CVE-2023-20273, and CVE-2024-20399, remain unverified.

item.title: How malicious AI powers the latest surge of advanced email threats
item.description: Email remains the primary attack vector for cybercriminals, with business email compromise (BEC) and vendor email compromise (VEC) attacks surging by 54% between 2023 and 2024. The rise of malicious AI tools has made phishing attacks more sophisticated, allowing threat actors to generate highly convincing emails that bypass traditional security measures. Attackers exploit personal data, multichannel phishing tactics, and outdated security tools to evade detection. Overreliance on employee awareness training and legacy defenses further weakens protection. To counter these threats, organizations must adopt AI-powered threat detection to proactively identify and mitigate evolving cyber risks.

item.title: Ukrainian hackers claim breach of Russian loan company linked to Putin’s ex-wife
item.description: The pro-Ukraine hacking group Cyber Alliance has claimed responsibility for a cyberattack on CarMoney, a major Russian microfinance firm reportedly linked to President Vladimir Putin’s ex-wife, Lyudmila Ocheretnaya. The attack forced CarMoney to shut down its systems after hackers sent false messages to customers, claiming the company was closing and forgiving debts. While CarMoney insists no personal data was compromised, the hackers claim to have obtained borrower information, including details on Russian military personnel. This incident follows a series of cyberattacks by the Ukrainian Cyber Alliance targeting Russian entities since the 2022 invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: UK government proposes ransomware legislation to curb payments and boost reporting
item.description: On February 19, the UK's home office reported the UK government's consultation on ransomware legislation aimed at reducing payments to cybercriminals and increasing incident reporting. Proposed measures seek to limit financial incentives for attackers, improve intelligence on ransomware transactions, and enhance government response capabilities. The consultation remains open until April 8, 2025, with responses invited from stakeholders.

item.title: Pegasus spyware infected private sector devices and at least on Europe government official
item.description: On February 19, iVerify, a US based cybersecurity firm, reported new detections of Pegasus spyware on 11 out of 18,000 devices tested in December, including those of business executives in real estate, logistics, and finance, as well as a European government official. The findings suggest broader use of commercial spyware beyond civil society targets. Some victims were monitored for years using multiple Pegasus variants.

item.title: Italy is under DDoS siege
item.description:
For the third consecutive day, the pro-Russian hacker group Noname057(16) has carried out a wave of cyberattacks targeting Italy. On Wednesday, the group's latest offensive focused on financial institutions, arms manufacturers, and public transportation companies.

Earlier this week, the hackers targeted around 20 websites, including those of Italy’s Guardia di Finanza, the Carabinieri, and multiple government ministries—Industry and Made in Italy, Foreign Affairs, Economy, Infrastructure and Transport, and Economic Development.

item.title: FBI Warns of Ghost Ransomware Attacks Targeting 70 Countries
item.description:
The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), and the Multi-State Information Sharing and Analysis Center (MS-ISAC) are releasing this joint advisory to disseminate known Ghost (Cring)— (“Ghost”)—ransomware IOCs and TTPs identified through FBI investigation as recently as January 2025.

Beginning early 2021, Ghost actors began attacking victims whose internet facing services ran outdated versions of software and firmware. This indiscriminate targeting of networks containing vulnerabilities has led to the compromise of organizations across more than 70 countries, including organizations in China. Ghost actors, located in China, conduct these widespread attacks for financial gain. Affected victims include critical infrastructure, schools and universities, healthcare, government networks, religious institutions, technology and manufacturing companies, and numerous small- and medium-sized businesses.

item.title: Microsoft’s Majorana 1 chip carves new path for quantum computing
item.description:
Microsoft introduced Majorana 1, the world’s first quantum chip powered by a new Topological Core architecture that it expects will realize quantum computers capable of solving meaningful, industrial-scale problems in years, not decades.

It leverages the world’s first topoconductor, a breakthrough type of material which can observe and control Majorana particles to produce more reliable and scalable qubits, which are the building blocks for quantum computers.

The topoconductor, or topological superconductor, is a special category of material that can create an entirely new state of matter – not a solid, liquid or gas but a topological state. This is harnessed to produce a more stable qubit that is fast, small and can be digitally controlled, without the tradeoffs required by current alternatives.

item.title: Analysis of an attack conducted by NSA
item.description: A cybersecurity researcher investigated how Chinese cybersecurity entities attribute cyber operations to the NSA, labeled as “APT-C-40.” Drawing from reports by Qihoo 360, Pangu Lab, and China’s National Computer Virus Emergency Response Center, the study examined claims that NSA’s Tailored Access Operations (TAO) allegedly hacked China’s Northwestern Polytechnical University in 2022 using sophisticated malware and zero-day exploits. The attack reportedly leveraged phishing, network traffic hijacking, and persistent backdoors to steal sensitive data. Chinese investigators attributed the breach to NSA based on working hours, language settings, and tool similarities with previously leaked cyber arsenals. The research also highlighted differences in Western and Chinese incident response methodologies, emphasizing China’s focus on big data analysis and collaboration across cybersecurity entities.

item.title: China-linked APT41 targets japanese firms in RevivalStone cyberespionage campaign
item.description: On February 18, Japanese cybersecurity company LAC reported that China-linked APT41 targeted Japanese manufacturing, materials, and energy sectors in a campaign dubbed RevivalStone. Active since at least 2012, Winnti deployed new malware variants in 2024, exploiting an SQL injection vulnerability in an ERP system to drop web shells. The group used stolen certificates and rootkits for persistence and covert access.

item.title: Mustang Panda novel techniques detected
item.description: Security researchers from TrendMicro have identified a Chinese state-sponsored cyber campaign conducted by Mustang Panda (also tracked as Earth Preta), which is leveraging Microsoft Application Virtualization Injector (MAVInject) to bypass ESET antivirus detection and deploy a TONESHELL backdoor variant. The campaign primarily targets government entities in the Asia-Pacific region, utilizing spearphishing tactics to deliver its payload.

item.title: GreenBravo novel infrastructure detected
item.description:
Among the newly observed TTPs, Recorded Future identified evidence that GreenBravo operators have registered infrastructure using Onion Mail accounts and pivoted to bulletproof hosting providers such as Stark Industries Solutions.

Historically, Recorded Future observed GreenBravo infrastructure linked to attacks targeting Israeli academics and Iranian investigative journalists. While no active targeting has surfaced at this time, the server configurations, matching Document Object Model (DOM) hashes, domain naming conventions, and use of specific infrastructure providers strongly indicate that the newly identified clusters are linked to this Iran-nexus group.

item.title: Russian Government Proposes Stricter Penalties to Tackle Cybercrime
item.description: On February 10, 2025, Russia approved sweeping cybersecurity reforms aimed at combating rising cyber threats by imposing harsher penalties, expanding law enforcement powers, and introducing public trials for cybercriminals. The legislation increases prison sentences to up to 15 years for hacking and infrastructure attacks, allows asset seizures—including cryptocurrencies—and bans convicted offenders from IT and finance jobs for a decade. Intelligence agencies gain enhanced surveillance tools, while companies face stricter security mandates. The reforms also streamline international extradition for cyber suspects, though critics warn of diplomatic tensions and privacy risks. If enacted, Russia’s cybercrime laws would be among the world’s strictest, with significant implications for digital governance and global cybersecurity cooperation.

item.title: North Korea's Kimsuky Taps Trusted Platforms to Attack South Korea
item.description: A recent campaign by North Korea-linked Kimsuky, dubbed DEEP#DRIVE by Securonix, highlights the group's increasing use of stealthy living-off-the-land techniques and trusted services like Dropbox to evade detection. The attack involved phishing emails distributing fake documents that executed PowerShell scripts to gather system data and download additional malware. While some activity targeted cryptocurrency users, the primary focus was espionage against South Korean government agencies and businesses. Researchers identified signs of over 8,000 compromised systems, with Kimsuky demonstrating improved operational security by using OAuth-based authentication for Dropbox storage and quickly dismantling infrastructure when detected. Experts recommend organizations implement stricter PowerShell execution policies, restrict shortcut file execution, and strengthen phishing defenses to counter such threats.

item.title: Russian state hackers spy on Ukrainian military through Signal app
item.description: Russian state-backed hackers are increasingly targeting Signal messenger accounts, particularly those used by Ukrainian military personnel and government officials, to intercept sensitive communications. Google’s security team reports that hackers exploit Signal’s “linked devices” feature by distributing malicious QR codes disguised as legitimate invites or security alerts, allowing attackers to access messages in real time. Some operations involve battlefield-captured devices, while others use phishing kits mimicking Ukrainian military applications. Russian groups, including Sandworm and UNC4221, have also deployed malware to exfiltrate Signal messages. While these attacks are driven by wartime intelligence needs, experts warn that similar threats could expand to other regions and secure messaging apps. Signal is working to enhance its security protections against such exploits.

item.title: DIU and the Armed Forces of Ukraine punished Gazprom for millions of dollars
item.description: On February 7-8, Ukrainian cyber specialists from the Defence Intelligence and Armed Forces of Ukraine launched a large-scale cyberattack on Russia's oil and gas infrastructure, primarily targeting Gazstroyprom, a key contractor of Gazprom, along with 22 other affiliated companies. The operation disabled over 120 servers and 10,000 computers, halting critical systems and destroying 2,000 terabytes of documentation. The attack caused significant disruption to companies supporting Russia’s military efforts, with estimated damages reaching tens to hundreds of millions of dollars.

item.title: Telegram Abused as C2 Channel for New Golang Backdoor
item.description: Netskope Threat Labs has identified a new Go-based backdoor malware, likely of Russian origin, that uses Telegram as its command and control (C2) channel. Discovered during threat hunting activities, the malware is fully functional despite appearing to be under development. It supports commands to execute PowerShell scripts, relaunch itself for persistence, and self-destruct, with all outputs sent to the Telegram channel. The use of Telegram for C2 makes detection difficult, as it blends with normal cloud app traffic. Netskope Advanced Threat Protection detects this threat as Trojan.Generic.37477095.

item.title: Password managers under increasing threat as infostealers triple and adapt
item.description: Picus Security reports a three-fold increase in malware targeting credentials stored in password managers and browser-based login vaults, marking a significant shift in cybercriminal tactics. Based on an analysis of one million malware samples, the study found that 93% of attacks align with just 10 MITRE ATT&CK techniques. Infostealers such as RedLine and Lumma, the latter offered as malware-as-a-service, are driving this surge by harvesting credentials from browsers, dedicated password managers, and cloud secrets management tools. Picus Labs co-founder Dr. Suleyman Ozarslan attributes the trend to stronger defenses in modern operating systems, which have pushed attackers to target less-protected credential stores.

item.title: Black-Hat SEO Poisioning Attacks Exploit Indian Government and Financial Websites
item.description: A large-scale black-hat SEO poisoning campaign has compromised over 150 Indian government and financial institution websites, redirecting millions of users to fraudulent gambling platforms promoting rummy and high-risk “investment” games. Exploiting vulnerabilities in .gov.in and .ac.in domains, attackers injected malicious JavaScript to hijack search engine rankings, directing mobile users to gambling sites while showing error pages to desktop visitors to evade detection. Analysts discovered over 12,000 spam pages on government servers using .shtml and .aspx uploads with financial keywords to dominate search results. The attackers leveraged Cloudflare and AWS infrastructure to mask their operations, deploying phishing kits mimicking banking portals. Victims lured with fake bonuses reported losses of ₹50,000–₹2 lakh, while takedowns by CERT-In and Google have been slowed by the campaign’s scale. With losses exceeding ₹200 crore annually, cybersecurity experts urge enhanced website audits, search ranking monitoring, and stricter file-upload controls to counter future threats.

item.title: An Italian journalist speaks about being targeted with Paragon spyware
item.description: Francesco Cancellato, editor-in-chief of the Italian newspaper Fanpage, revealed he was targeted by spyware from Paragon Solutions via WhatsApp, alongside three other journalists critical of the Italian government. Cancellato, known for undercover investigations into far-right political parties, including Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's Brothers of Italy, suspects the attack originated in Italy but cannot confirm government involvement. He chose to go public to highlight the growing misuse of spyware against journalists and activists, warning of its impact on press freedom and democracy.

item.title: Cyberattack on the University of the Bundeswehr Munich
item.description: The Bundeswehr University in Munich experienced a cyberattack on its data centre, detected on 23 January 2025, with attackers accessing a central IT service. The university, which trains Bundeswehr personnel in fields such as cybersecurity and intelligence, is working to assess and mitigate the impact, though only internal university systems were affected. While there is no evidence of data deletion or encryption, reports suggest that personal information of students and staff, including bank details and phone numbers, may be compromised.

item.title: Propaganda Watch: China’s International Communication Centres
item.description: China’s International Communication Centres (ICCs), operated under the Central Propaganda Department of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), aim to shape global narratives and promote pro-Beijing messaging. Since their launch in 2018, over 100 centres have been established, with operations expanding globally through media partnerships and social media campaigns. ICCs use tactics such as AI-generated content, collaboration with foreign influencers, and covert social media accounts to influence public opinion, while also targeting sensitive issues like Taiwan and Tibet through regional messaging initiatives.

item.title: Alleged data leak at Leonardo
item.description:
The ransomware leak page associated with the victim identified as Leonardo, a well-known global aerospace, defense, and security company, details a significant data breach affecting their operations. According to the extracted information, the ransomware group’s name is threeam, and they have disclosed data regarding 39 users and 62 third-party entities. Shortly after the claim Leonardo has issued a public statement, reading "Leonardo states that rumors claiming the hacker group ThreeAM breached Leonardo Spa's computer systems are completely unfounded."

Reference

item.title: Russian influence operations evolving ahead German Federal elections
item.description: State-affiliated influence operations aiming at interfering with German federal elections scheduled for February 23, 2025. Key objectives of these influence operations include fomenting domestic unrest, manipulating public discourse, eroding trust in election security, and promoting skepticism toward the EU and NATO. Moreover, these campaigns seek to amplify criticism of the United States while fostering support for political entities such as Alternative für Deutschland (AfD), perceived as aligning with Russian strategic interests.

item.title: Japan approves Cyber Defense Bill to counter sophisticated threats
item.description: On February 7, Japan's Cabinet approved the Cyber Response Capability Enhancement Bill to strengthen defenses against sophisticated cyberattacks targeting critical infrastructure. This legislation aligns with the National Security Strategy (December 2022) and incorporates expert recommendations from November 29, 2024. The bill includes active cyber defense measures, such as proactively detecting threats and shutting down enemy servers during an incident to mitigate potential harm.

item.title: North Korea targets crypto developers via NPM supply chain attack
item.description: North Korea's Lazarus Group has launched a new cyber campaign, Operation Marstech Mayhem, targeting Web3 developers and cryptocurrency wallets by embedding the Marstech1 implant into NPM packages and GitHub repositories. According to SecurityScorecard, attackers use stolen API keys and obfuscated JavaScript code to compromise wallets across Windows, macOS, and Linux, affecting at least 233 victims so far. The implant enables Lazarus to access and steal cryptocurrency funds, exploiting the software supply chain to spread the malware more widely. Meanwhile, Microsoft reported that Kimsuky, another North Korean group, has been impersonating South Korean officials to trick victims into running malicious PowerShell commands for espionage purposes. The incidents highlight North Korea's continued focus on financially and strategically motivated cyber operations.

item.title: Ukraine warns of growing AI use in Russian cyber-espionage operations
item.description: Russian state-backed hackers are increasingly using AI to analyse stolen data, making their cyber operations more precise and effective, according to Ukrainian cyber officials. By applying machine learning, attackers filter essential information from compromised mailboxes to create highly personalised phishing messages targeting military personnel. These messages often include names, ranks, and official documents to deceive victims into clicking malicious links. Ukraine has also observed growing collaboration between Russian hackers and cybercriminal groups, with AI used to process stolen data for espionage. The use of AI in Russian cyber campaigns has raised concerns globally, with officials warning about potential applications like deepfake propaganda and enhanced infrastructure attacks.

item.title: Microsoft uncovers BadPilot campaign by Russian Seashell Blizzard subgroup
