item.description: On February 12, Microsoft revealed that a subgroup within the Russian state actor Seashell Blizzard (aka Sandworm) has been conducting a multiyear global access operation, termed the "BadPilot campaign." This subgroup exploited vulnerabilities in internet-facing infrastructure to persist on high-value targets across sectors like energy, telecommunications, and government, expanding their operations beyond Eastern Europe since at least 2021.

item.title: Salt Typhoon Exploits Vulnerable Cisco Devices of Global Telecommunications Providers
item.description: Between December 2024 and January 2025, the Chinese state-sponsored group RedMike, linked to Salt Typhoon, exploited unpatched Cisco network devices targeting global telecommunications providers, including affiliates in the US, UK, South Africa, and several universities across multiple countries. The group gained access through vulnerabilities to establish persistent access and monitor communications, likely for intelligence gathering. RedMike targeted over 1,000 devices, with a focus on critical infrastructure and academic institutions conducting research in telecommunications and technology.

item.title: Kimsuky uses PowerShell exploits to target international affairs professionals and NGOs
item.description: On February 11, Microsoft reported that North Korea-linked Kimsuky, also known as Emerald Sleet, is using a tactic where victims are deceived into running PowerShell as an administrator and executing malicious code. This facilitates data exfiltration via a remote desktop tool. The group primarily targets individuals working in international affairs, particularly those focused on Northeast Asia, in America, Europe, and East Asia.

item.title: A new wave of Mirai-based botnet exploiting vulnerabilities in routers and smart devices
item.description: A Mirai-based botnet has been actively exploiting vulnerabilities in routers and smart devices, primarily targeting industrial and home networks globally. The Shadowserver Foundation reported the botnet’s use of flaws in devices from various devices to gain unauthorised access and conduct large-scale Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks. The attackers infiltrate devices by exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities and using brute-force techniques on weak passwords. With around 15,000 active nodes, the botnet appears motivated by financial gain through DDoS-for-hire services.

item.title: Have I Been Pwned likely to ban resellers from buying subs, citing ‘sh*tty behavior’ and onerous support requests
item.description: Troy Hunt, founder of Have I Been Pwned (HIBP), is considering banning resellers from the service due to their disproportionate demand for support. Although resellers represent only 0.86% of subscribers, they account for over 15% of support requests, often requiring more time and effort to resolve. Hunt noted instances of resellers significantly marking up subscription costs and raising complex queries about pricing and policies. While he is exploring automation to reduce this burden, he remains strongly inclined to discontinue reseller partnerships in the coming weeks. HIBP will continue working with managed service providers (MSPs), who are seen as adding genuine value.

item.title: LLMjacking exploits target AI models like DeepSeek
item.description: Cybercriminals are increasingly targeting emerging AI models like DeepSeek through a tactic known as LLMjacking, which involves stealing API keys and cloud credentials to access these models illicitly. The Sysdig Threat Research Team reported that attackers use covert reverse proxies and dynamic domain names to disguise their activity, allowing them to profit by selling unauthorised access online. Victims face significant financial losses, with one case involving nearly $39,000 in unauthorised charges. The attacks are facilitated through underground forums and tools that help conceal infrastructure.

item.title: Cybercrime: A Multifaceted National Security Threat
item.description: Mandiant Consulting reported a significant rise in financially motivated cybercrime in 2024, with nearly four times more incidents than state-backed intrusions. Cybercriminals increasingly target critical sectors like healthcare, causing disruptions with impacts similar to state-sponsored attacks. Additionally, cybercrime and state-backed hacking often intersect, with countries like Russia, Iran, China, and North Korea leveraging criminal groups for espionage, disruption, and revenue generation.

item.title: Internet and social media restriction in Democratic Republic of Congo
item.description: On February 10, third-party monitor Internet Society reported ongoing social media restrictions in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). On January 27, internet monitor NetBlocks reported significant internet disruption in Goma. On February 3, NetBlocks further reported multiple mobile application stores were blocked to prevent users from downloading VPNs to circumvent social media restrictions. DRC authorities have suspended internet access since January 23 in an attempt to contain misinformation.

item.title: Hacker attack on LUP clinics: Medical care remains secure
item.description: The German LUP-Klinikum Helene von Bülow experienced a cyberattack on its electronic systems during the night of February 10. The police were notified on Monday morning, and investigations have been initiated by the Schwerin Criminal Police and the State Criminal Office. As a precaution, the clinics in Hagenow and Ludwigslust were disconnected from email and online services, and their emergency rooms were temporarily deregistered, although critical cases are still being treated. Despite the attack, medical care at all affected locations remains fully operational.

item.title: Sandworm APT Targets Ukrainian Users with Trojanized Microsoft KMS Activation Tools in Cyber Espionage Campaigns
item.description: EclecticIQ analysts report that Sandworm (APT44), a Russian GRU-backed threat actor, is conducting a cyber espionage campaign targeting Ukrainian Windows users. Since late 2023, Sandworm has exploited pirated Microsoft Key Management Service activators and fake Windows updates to deploy BACKORDER, a malware loader that installs Dark Crystal RAT (DcRAT) for data theft and espionage. Evidence linking Sandworm to this campaign includes shared infrastructure, consistent tactics, and the use of Russian-language development tools. Ukraine's widespread reliance on pirated software, especially in government sectors, has significantly increased vulnerability to such attacks, posing risks to national security and critical infrastructure.

item.title: India's Cybercrime Problems Grow as Nation Digitizes
item.description: India is experiencing a sharp rise in cybercrime, with cyber fraud against citizens increasing by 51% in the past year and businesses facing significantly more cyberattacks than the global average. In 2024, over 1.7 million cybercrime complaints were filed, up from 1.1 million in 2023, with nearly half of the attacks originating from cybercriminal hubs in Cambodia, Myanmar, and Laos. Businesses are increasingly targeted, facing more denial-of-service attacks and threats to mobile APIs. The government is responding with new data protection laws, secure banking domains, international cooperation with the US, and initiatives to train 5,000 cybersecurity professionals, though challenges remain in addressing the growing threat.

item.title: Delivering Malware Through Abandoned Amazon S3 Buckets
item.description: Researchers identified and registered around 150 abandoned Amazon S3 buckets, previously used in commercial and open-source software, government systems, and infrastructure pipelines, for just $400. These buckets, though abandoned, still received eight million requests over two months from systems seeking updates, highlighting a major supply-chain vulnerability. Had this been a malicious operation, attackers could have inserted malware into the buckets, leading to widespread compromise similar to the SolarWinds attack but on a larger scale. Since the original developers no longer control these buckets, they can't patch vulnerabilities or notify affected users, exposing significant flaws in software supply-chain security.

item.title: New Chinese Hacking Campaign Targets Manufacturing Firms to Steal IP
item.description: Check Point is investigating a new Chinese cyber-espionage campaign targeting suppliers in sensitive manufacturing sectors, including chemical products and infrastructure components, in the US and globally. According to Lotem Finkelsteen, Check Point's Director of Threat Intelligence, the hackers are infiltrating networks via vulnerabilities in edge devices like IoT equipment and virtual private servers, aiming to steal intellectual property and gain insights into supply chains. While the group shares tactics with known Chinese state-sponsored actors, specific attribution is pending. The full report will be released soon, highlighting the growing aggressiveness of Chinese cyber activities despite increased exposure.

item.title: U.S. adversaries increasingly turning to cybercriminals and their malware for help
item.description: A Google report reveals that countries like Russia, China, Iran, and North Korea are increasingly leveraging cybercriminal tools and networks to advance their cyber-espionage efforts. Russia, driven by the war in Ukraine, has been using malware commonly associated with cybercriminals, such as Radthief and Warzone, to support its operations. This trend is attributed to resource constraints and operational demands, making criminal tools a cheaper and more deniable option. Other nations, like China, have also used cybercriminal groups to mask their espionage activities. Google warns that this growing overlap between state and criminal cyber actors poses a significant national security threat.

item.title: Global police operation seizes 8base ransomware gang leak site
item.description: An international coalition of law enforcement agencies from Europe, Japan, the U.S., and the U.K. has seized the dark web leak site of the 8base ransomware gang, a financially motivated hacking group first identified in 2022. The Bavarian State Criminal Police Office led the operation on behalf of the Public Prosecutor General in Bamberg, with the U.K.’s National Crime Agency confirming its supportive role. 8base, linked to the RansomHouse extortion group, is known for double-extortion tactics—encrypting victims' data and threatening to leak it unless ransoms are paid. The group has targeted multiple sectors in the U.S., including healthcare, and previously claimed responsibility for a cyberattack on the United Nations Development Programme.

item.title: Dutch Minister announces plans for new National Cyber Security Center
item.description: The Dutch National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), the Digital Trust Center (DTC), and the Computer Security Incident Response Team for digital service providers (CSIRT-DSP) will merge into a new, unified NCSC, as announced by Minister Beljaarts. This consolidation aims to improve synergy and reduce fragmentation in the government's cybersecurity landscape. The new NCSC will serve multiple roles, including as a national CSIRT, knowledge and advisory center, execution coordinator, and sector-specific CSIRT, targeting vital sectors like banking, energy, telecom, and the wider business community. This year will focus on joint communication efforts, shared products, and the establishment of an advisory board with external stakeholders to guide strategic decisions. The integration process began last year, with CSIRT-DSP now fully operating under the NCSC, and the complete transition is expected by January next year.

item.title: Von der Leyen launches world’s largest public-private partnership to win AI race
item.description: Ursula von der Leyen announced a €50 billion investAI initiative and an additional €8 billion for AI Factories during the AI Action Summit in Paris, signaling the EU's strong commitment to advancing in the global AI race. Emphasizing growth and investment, von der Leyen highlighted that these funds will complement the €150 billion private EU AI Champions initiative, creating the largest public-private AI partnership globally. She also introduced plans for AI Gigafactories, aiming to replicate the collaborative success of CERN and significantly boost private sector involvement, asserting that global leadership in AI is still within reach.

item.title: Fast-track armed forces recruitment launched to boost UK cyber defence
item.description: The UK Ministry of Defence has launched a new fast-track recruitment scheme to address the growing cyber threat by accelerating the training and deployment of cyber specialists within the armed forces. Recruits with digital skills will undergo a condensed basic training followed by specialized instruction at the Defence Cyber Academy, enabling them to enter operational roles by the end of 2025. This initiative aims to bolster the UK’s cyber defenses in response to increasing cyberattacks on military networks and is part of the government’s broader effort to tackle recruitment challenges and adapt to the evolving nature of warfare in the digital age.

item.title: Musk’s DOGE poses cybersecurity risks to US federal systems
item.description: According to a report by The Atlantic on February 7, Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) has accessed critical US federal IT systems, including those of the Treasury Department and Office of Personnel Management. Cybersecurity experts warn that DOGE’s untrained personnel could unintentionally or deliberately compromise these systems, posing national security risks. The full impact is unclear, but concerns grow over data breaches, system disruptions, and long-term cybersecurity threats.

item.title: Commission to withdraw proposed ePrivacy Regulation
item.description: ----I only have the title, the content is behind paywall and I was not able to find alternative source at the time of reporting----

item.title: Hackers breach Microsoft IIS services using Cityworks RCE bug
item.description: Hackers are exploiting a high-severity remote code execution (RCE) vulnerability (CVE-2025-0994) in Cityworks, a GIS-based asset and work order management software, to run malicious code on customers' Microsoft IIS web servers. The flaw, identified as a severe deserialization issue, affects critical infrastructure across various U.S. cities and utilities, including Greeley, Baltimore County, and Sacramento Suburban Water District, posing risks of service disruptions, data breaches, and public safety threats. Trimble, the developer of Cityworks, is working on a fix to be included in the next software update and has urged on-premises customers to apply patches immediately, while Cityworks Online deployments will be updated automatically. Investigations revealed overprivileged permissions and misconfigured directories in several deployments, prompting CISA to advise organizations to conduct risk assessments before implementing defensive measures.

item.title: Europol Warns Financial Sector of “Imminent” Quantum Threat
item.description: Europol has warned Europe’s financial services sector to start preparing for the transition to quantum-safe cryptography due to the growing threat of "store now, decrypt later" (SNDL) attacks. These attacks involve cybercriminals stealing encrypted data today with the intention of decrypting it in the future, once quantum computers—capable of breaking current public key cryptography—become available. While such quantum machines are expected to be at least a decade away, accelerated scientific breakthroughs and increased funding could shorten this timeline. Failure to act could jeopardize the security of financial transactions, authentication processes, and digital contracts, posing significant risks to the financial sector.

item.title: OpenAI investigates potential leak of 20 million users' data
item.description: Cybercriminals claim to have stolen login data from over 20 million OpenAI accounts, raising serious concerns about potential data breaches affecting ChatGPT users. The data, advertised on a darknet forum, includes email addresses and passwords being sold cheaply, though researchers and security experts remain skeptical about the legitimacy of these claims. OpenAI has stated that there is no evidence of a system compromise but is actively investigating the situation and may conduct a mass review of accounts. If confirmed, the breach could expose sensitive user data, including confidential company projects and communications, significantly impacting user trust and security.

item.title: North Korean APT Kimsuky Uses forceCopy Malware to Steal Browser-Stored Credentials
item.description: The North Korean hacking group Kimsuky, also known as APT43, has been carrying out targeted phishing attacks to steal sensitive information, according to AhnLab Security Intelligence Center (ASEC). These attacks use deceptive emails to trick victims into opening malicious attachments, allowing the hackers to gain access to their systems. Once inside, Kimsuky deploys various tools to steal login credentials, monitor user activity, and maintain long-term access to the compromised networks. This marks a shift in the group’s tactics, as they increasingly rely on new methods to strengthen their control over targeted systems. The attacks pose serious risks, particularly to organizations handling sensitive data, as Kimsuky is linked to North Korea’s primary intelligence agency.

item.title: 35% Year-over-Year Decrease in Ransomware Payments, Less than Half of Recorded Incidents Resulted in Victim Payments
item.description: In 2024, the ransomware landscape underwent significant changes, marked by a 35% decline in ransom payments compared to the previous year. This drop was driven by increased law enforcement actions, stronger international cooperation, and a growing number of victims refusing to pay. In response, attackers adapted by rebranding existing ransomware strains and accelerating their operations, with some groups targeting organizations like Snowflake. Disruptions to major groups like LockBit and BlackCat, alongside high-profile arrests, fragmented the ransomware ecosystem, leading to smaller, less coordinated attacks. Despite an increase in ransomware incidents, fewer victims chose to pay, reflecting improved cyber defenses and resilience. However, the evolving tactics of attackers and the rise of new ransomware strains highlight the ongoing threat and need for continued vigilance.

item.title: Russian role in buying software for EU border system probed
item.description: European prosecutors are investigating how the Moscow office of French IT firm Atos contributed to building the EU’s new electronic border system, which will create the bloc’s largest personal information database. Atos used its Russian staff to procure software for the project in 2021, raising significant security concerns due to the potential access of Russia’s FSB security service, as Atos Russia operated under an FSB license. Although no security breaches have been identified, and Atos has since divested from its Russian operations, the involvement of Moscow-based staff in such a sensitive project has prompted scrutiny from the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and the EU’s anti-fraud watchdog, Olaf. This situation has delayed the project’s launch and highlighted vulnerabilities in the EU’s handling of critical infrastructure security.

item.title: UK government demands Apple backdoor to encrypted cloud data: report
item.description: UK government officials have reportedly ordered Apple to create a backdoor granting authorities access to all users' encrypted iCloud data under the Investigatory Powers Act 2016, known as the Snoopers' Charter. The demand, issued in January, seeks broad, unrestricted access to encrypted files globally, rather than targeting specific accounts. In response, Apple is expected to withdraw its Advanced Data Protection service from UK users, limiting the impact to the UK while maintaining encryption protections elsewhere, including in the US. This move raises significant privacy concerns, as Apple has previously warned that such backdoors could also be exploited by hackers, compromising user security worldwide.

item.title: India's RBI Introduces Exclusive "bank.in" Domain to Combat Digital Banking Fraud
item.description: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has announced the introduction of a dedicated "bank.in" internet domain exclusively for Indian banks to combat rising digital financial fraud. This initiative aims to reduce cybersecurity threats like phishing and strengthen trust in digital banking by ensuring more secure financial services. The Institute for Development and Research in Banking Technology (IDRBT) will oversee domain registrations, set to begin in April 2025. Additionally, the RBI plans to launch a separate "fin.in" domain for non-bank financial entities and implement Additional Factor of Authentication (AFA) for cross-border online transactions, adding another layer of security to digital payments. These measures are designed to enhance user confidence and safeguard the integrity of India's digital financial ecosystem.

item.title: Baltics brace for cyberattacks as they depart Russian electricity grid
item.description:
Europe’s Baltics are bracing for cyberattacks as they plan to decouple from a Soviet-era joint power grid with Russia and Belarus this weekend.

Estonia has prepared for many possible risk scenarios regarding our departure from BRELL, including cyberthreats,” Gert Auväärt, head of Estonia’s Cyber Security Centre, told POLITICO in a written response. He said the country is ready to call in its cyber reserve, which includes the Estonian Defense League’s cyber unit, a volunteer group of cyber defenders.

item.title: France releases report about manipulation of information targeting 2024 Romanian presidential elections
item.description: The French General Secretariat for Defense and National Security has issued a report that provides information on the manipulations of the information that targeted the Romanian presidential election of 2024, the results of which were cancelled by the Romanian Constitutional Court on 6 December. Most of the evidence presented came from an analysis carried out between 25 November and 20 December 2024, which relates in particular to the operating procedures observed on the TikTok platform, intended to artificially promote certain contents, as well as the instrumentalization of influences.

item.title: UK technology heads priorities cybersecurity in 2025
item.description: A recent BIE report reveals that UK technology leaders are prioritizing cybersecurity in 2025 due to rising cyber threats linked to AI and digital transformation. Surveying 255 senior leaders, the report highlights that 50% of businesses faced security breaches in the past year, costing the economy billions. Despite improved data governance from Chief Data Officers, challenges in sourcing cybersecurity expertise persist, compounded by a significant technology skills gap acknowledged by 98% of respondents. With AI enabling more sophisticated cyber-attacks, leaders are increasingly reliant on interim cybersecurity professionals to bridge skill gaps, mitigate risks during business transformations, and fast-track growth while addressing issues like legacy systems, budget constraints, and resistance to change.

item.title: 21% of CISOs pressured to not report compliance issues
item.description: A study of 600 CISOs worldwide reveals that 21% of security leaders have faced pressure from executives or board members to avoid reporting compliance issues, highlighting a growing conflict between corporate interests and regulatory obligations. While 59% of CISOs indicated they would become whistleblowers if compliance was ignored, many are caught between personal liability risks and organizational pressure to protect reputations. Increased regulatory scrutiny under frameworks like GDPR, SEC rules, and DORA has intensified these challenges, with CISOs often lacking sufficient budgetary and executive support to ensure compliance. This tension is contributing to job dissatisfaction, with nearly 25% of security leaders considering leaving their roles, emphasizing the need for stronger security governance, board-level commitment, and a culture of compliance.

item.title: Russian actors exploiting 7-Zip vulnerability to deliver SmokeLoader against Ukrainian targets
item.description: In September 2024, researchers from Trend Micro Zero Day Initiative (ZDI) Threat Hunting Team identified the exploitation of a now-patched zero-day vulnerability in 7-Zip, indexed with CVE-2025-0411, as part of a Russian cyberespionage campaign targeting Ukrainian entities. The vulnerability, patched in 7-Zip version 24.09 released on November 30, 2024, if exploited, allows attackers to bypass Windows Mark-of-the-Web (MoTW) protections, enabling the execution of malicious files without standard security warnings. The campaign leveraged homoglyph attacks to disguise malicious payloads as legitimate documents, increasing the likelihood of successful exploitation. In such attacks, attackers deceive victims by manipulating file names using Cyrillic homoglyph characters, making malicious executables appear as legitimate Microsoft Word documents.

item.title: Hackers Using Fake Microsoft ADFS Login Pages to Steal Credentials
item.description: A global phishing campaign is underway, exploiting a legacy Microsoft authentication system to steal user credentials and bypass multi-factor authentication (MFA), targeting over 150 organizations. The attackers employ a combination of social engineering and technical manipulation. Phishing emails, mimicking legitimate notifications, lure victims to spoofed ADFS login pages. These emails often use urgent tones, warn of supposed updates or policy changes, and incorporate legitimate branding, logos, and even contact information to appear genuine.

item.title: Massive Malware Repository Discovered on GitHub
item.description: A GitHub repository named “The-MALWARE-Repo,” has come under scrutiny for hosting hundreds of malware samples, including Remote Access Trojans (RATs), ransomware, spyware, viruses, worms, and more. Each folder in the repository includes executable files and scripts associated with these malware categories. According to the post from cyberundergroundfeed, While the repository could serve as a valuable resource for malware analysts and cybersecurity researchers, it poses significant risks if accessed irresponsibly.

item.title: After Texas and Italy, Taiwan and Australia also bans Chinese AI DeepSeek
item.description:
Taiwan on 04. February banned government departments from using Chinese startup DeepSeek's artificial intelligence (AI) service as it was a security risk, toughening language from last week which said it should not be used. During a cabinet meeting, Taiwan Premier Cho Jung-tai said DeepSeek was banned from use in all government agencies "to ensure the country's information security", his office said in a statement.

There were also concerns about censorship on DeepSeek and the risk of data ending up in China, the statement said.

Australia has banned DeepSeek from all government devices on the advice of security agencies, a top official said on Wednesday (05. February), citing privacy and malware risks posed by China's breakout AI programme.

Risks included that uploaded information "might not be kept private", government cyber security envoy Andrew Charlton told national broadcaster ABC, and that applications such as DeepSeek "may expose you to malware".

Reference

Reference

item.title: Kazakhstan launches internal investigations over UAC-0063 attacks
item.description: Kazakhstan has announced plans to audit its Foreign Ministry following an intrusion that cybersecurity researchers suspect may have ties to Russian state-sponsored operations. The Kazakh Digital Ministry launched an investigation after a recent analysis detailed a cyberespionage campaign targeting diplomatic entities across Central Asia, including Kazakhstan.

item.title: Swedish authorities release seized cargo ship ruling out sabotage in Baltic Sea cable incidents
item.description:
The Swedish Prosecution Authority (SPA) announced that it is releasing the Vezhen, a cargo ship previously suspected of sabotaging a communications cable in the Baltic Sea. Investigators determined that the cable break was not an act of sabotage, but instead resulted from a combination of weather conditions, equipment deficiencies, and seamanship errors.

The Vezhen was seized on January 26. Swedish authorities have now concluded their investigations finding that although the ship was confirmed to be responsible for the cable break, no indications of deliberate interference were found.

item.title: Contec Patient Monitors Not Malicious, but Still Pose Big Risk to Healthcare
item.description: The Contec CMS8000 patient monitors, widely used in healthcare, have been found to contain an insecure design flaw that exposes patient data and enables potential remote attacks, according to cybersecurity firm Claroty. While the US cybersecurity agency CISA and the FDA initially classified the issue as a hidden backdoor, Claroty clarifies that the hardcoded IP address involved is explicitly documented in the product manual for Central Management System (CMS) connections. The flaw allows attackers to execute arbitrary code via insecure firmware updates, though physical access is required to trigger this process. Additionally, the device communicates with a publicly routable IP, posing risks of data leakage and malicious commands. Claroty demonstrated a proof-of-concept attack confirming remote exploitation potential and recommends blocking the 202.114.4.0/24 subnet, restricting network access, and replacing vulnerable devices unless the firmware is updated.

item.title: Chinese-Linked APT Targets Telecoms in South Asia
item.description:
Unit 42 researchers uncovered a cyberespionage campaign, CL-STA-0048, targeting high-value organizations in South Asia, including a telecom company, with evidence suggesting a Chinese state-backed APT group. The attackers persistently exploited vulnerable internet-facing services, eventually breaching an unpatched MSSQL server to escalate privileges and deploy malware. They employed stealthy exfiltration techniques, including DNS-based data theft via ping commands and SQLcmd for extracting sensitive information. PlugX RAT played a central role, utilizing DLL sideloading to evade detection, while Cobalt Strike and privilege escalation tools enabled persistence. The attackers leveraged SoftEther VPN and a custom downloader for C2 communications and used a unique "Hex Staging" method for malware deployment. Unit 42 linked CL-STA-0048 to Chinese APT groups like DragonRank, based on shared TTPs, infrastructure, and malware use.

Reference

item.title: Law enforcement takes down two largest cybercrime forums in the world
item.description: A Europol-supported operation, led by German authorities and involving law enforcement from eight countries, has led to the takedown of the two largest cybercrime forums in the world. The two platforms, Cracked and Nulled, had more than 10 million users in total. Both of these underground economy forums offered a quick entry point into the cybercrime scene. These sites worked as one-stop shops and were used not only for discussions on cybercrime but also as marketplaces for illegal goods and cybercrime-as-a-service, such as stolen data, malware or hacking tools. Investigators estimate that suspects earned EUR 1 million in criminal profits.

item.title: OpenAI unveils a new ChatGPT agent for ‘deep research’
item.description: OpenAI has introduced "deep research," a new AI-powered feature in ChatGPT designed for in-depth and complex research, particularly for professionals in finance, science, policy, and engineering. Available to ChatGPT Pro users with future expansions to Plus, Team, and Enterprise tiers, deep research allows users to query multiple sources, analyze data, and receive detailed, citation-backed responses within 5 to 30 minutes. It leverages an enhanced version of OpenAI’s o3 reasoning model, optimized for web browsing and data analysis, but still has accuracy limitations and potential issues with misinformation. OpenAI plans to add visual outputs and support for specialized data sources in the future.

item.title: EU Commission to take a ‘holistic’ approach against Temu, Shein
item.description: The European Commission is planning a holistic strategy to address the surge in imports from major e-commerce platforms like Temu and Shein, which doubled in 2024 to 4.6 billion low-value goods, mostly from China. The draft proposal includes tightening EU customs rules, enhancing consumer protection enforcement, and implementing environmental regulations requiring producers to manage recycled waste. National customs authorities will receive more resources, and AI will be used to detect illegal goods. A new EU Customs Authority will centralize data processing. Meanwhile, Temu faces an EU investigation under the Digital Services Act (DSA), while Shein, though under DSA regulations, is not currently under formal scrutiny. The draft report is expected to be published on Wednesday.

item.title: DeepSeek is being banned for official use (Italy, USA)
item.description:
Texas has banned Chinese AI company DeepSeek and social media apps Xiaohongshu (RedNote) and Lemon8 from all state-issued devices, citing concerns over data-harvesting and national security risks. Governor Greg Abbott emphasized the state’s commitment to protecting infrastructure from foreign threats, following similar actions against TikTok. Meanwhile, Italy’s data protection authority (Garante) has blocked DeepSeek’s chatbot service due to insufficient transparency regarding data collection, storage, and legal compliance. The regulator demanded clarification on data sources, processing purposes, and storage locations, but DeepSeek denied its operations in Italy, leading to an ongoing investigation.

The Garante’s order to block DeepSeek's chatbot in Italy took immediate effect after the company’s responses were deemed totally insufficient. DeepSeek removed its AI assistant from Italian app stores but claimed it was not subject to local regulations, refusing to provide further information. Italian authorities warned that non-cooperation would keep the ban in place, with some users still able to access the chatbot. The case has drawn broader European scrutiny, as data regulators in Ireland and France are also questioning DeepSeek over its privacy policies. Italy’s Garante, known for its strict stance on AI-related privacy issues, had previously blocked ChatGPT over EU privacy rule concerns.

Reference

item.title: Spyware distribution campaign over WhatsApp detected
item.description: The Guardian reported that WhatsApp intervened to stop a spyware campaign attributed to the Israeli cybersecurity firm Paragon Solutions. The operation reportedly compromised close to 100 individuals, primarily targeting journalists and civil society figures. The spyware, identified as "Graphite", was suspected of being delivered through malicious PDFs distributed in WhatsApp group chats. Cybersecurity experts pointed out that the attack used a zero-click technique, enabling it to infect devices without user engagement. Following the discovery, WhatsApp demanded that Paragon Solutions halt its activities and signaled that legal action was being considered.

item.title: Taiwan-Matsu undersea cables cut, suspected Chinese involvement raises concerns
item.description: On January 22, two undersea cables connecting Taiwan and the Matsu Islands were reported broken, with initial faults occurring on January 15. Chunghwa Telecom, Taiwan's largest integrated telecommunications operator, announced that communication between Taiwan and the Matsu Islands was restored on January 24. Authorities suspect that Chinese vessels may have been involved in damaging these cables, raising concerns about potential "gray zone operations" by China to disrupt Taiwan's communications.

item.title: Malware Discovered in Healthcare Patient Monitors
item.description:
Traced to Chinese IP Address The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has issued a critical advisory on multiple vulnerabilities in Contec Health’s CMS8000 Patient Monitor, which pose serious risks such as remote attacks, data breaches, and unauthorized access. These flaws, with CVSS v4 scores reaching 9.3, could be exploited with minimal effort, threatening healthcare systems globally. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has also issued a safety warning, emphasizing the severity of these security issues.

Reference

item.title: Threat actors exploit .gov domains for phishing campaigns
item.description: Cofense Intelligence's report highlights the abuse of government (.gov) domains for phishing attacks from November 2022 to November 2024. Threat actors exploited these domains primarily for credential phishing and open redirects, leveraging trusted government URLs to bypass secure email gateways (SEGs). Open redirects, particularly those linked to CVE-2024-25608 in the Liferay platform, were a major vector of attack, allowing cybercriminals to redirect users to phishing sites. While U.S.-based .gov domains accounted for 9% of the cases, they were the third most exploited, with campaigns frequently mimicking Microsoft to steal credentials.

item.title: Belgian airspace reopens, but flights still disrupted
item.description: The Belgian airspace has reopened after a technical problem at air traffic controller skeyes on Thursday afternoon. Flights to and from Brussels Airport are still reportedly disrupted. No planes were temporarily able to land or take off at Belgium's main airports, including Brussels Airport. At around 15:00, it emerged that the air traffic control system used by skeyes to operate Belgian airspace was "not functioning as required," said skeyes spokesperson Kurt Verwilligen.

item.title: Wiz Research Uncovers Exposed DeepSeek Database Leaking Sensitive Information, Including Chat History
item.description: DeepSeek is the new AI solution that, since it was announced recently has made into the news. Wiz Research has identified a publicly accessible ClickHouse database belonging to DeepSeek, which allows full control over database operations, including the ability to access internal data. The exposure includes over a million lines of log streams containing chat history, secret keys, backend details, and other highly sensitive information. As DeepSeek made waves in the AI space, the Wiz Research team set out to assess its external security posture and identify any potential vulnerabilities.

item.title: DeepSeek AI app blocked in Italy and investigated in Ireland
item.description: On January 29, DeepSeek's AI Assistant app was removed from Apple and Google stores in Italy due to data privacy concerns. Italy’s data protection authority requested more details, while Ireland’s Data Protection Commission launched a GDPR investigation. Meanwhile, the US National Security Council announced a national security review of the app, raising further scrutiny over its data collection and privacy practices.

item.title: Russia-nexus APT possibly related to APT28 conducts cyber espionage on Central Asia and Kazakhstan diplomatic relations
item.description:
Since the start of the Ukraine war , the geopolitical landscape of Central Asia has undergone significant shifts, impacting the region's relationships with both Russia and China. Russia's influence, once dominant, has noticeably declined due to its actions in Ukraine, which have damaged its reputation as a regional security guarantor, with some Central Asian countries feeling that Russia doesn't respect their sovereignty.

Bitdefender Labs warns of an active cyber-espionage campaign targeting organizations in Central Asia and European countries. The group, tracked as UAC-0063, employs sophisticated tactics to infiltrate high-value targets, including government entities and diplomatic missions, expanding their operations into Europe.

Reference

item.title: Hackers from China, Iran, and North Korea use AI tools to enhance cyberattacks On
item.description: January 29, The Wall Street Journal reported that hackers from China, Iran, and North Korea are using US AI products, including Google's Gemini, to enhance their cyberattacks. They appear to treat the platform more as a research assistant than a strategic asset, relying on it for tasks that boost productivity rather than developing new, advanced hacking techniques. These tools assist in tasks like reconnaissance and anomaly detection evasion.

item.title: US Cyber Agency’s Future Role in Elections Remains Murky Under the Trump Administration
item.description:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has played a key role in securing election systems, but its future is uncertain amid Republican criticism and changes under the Trump administration. President Trump has not appointed a new leader for CISA, and Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem has suggested the agency has strayed from its core mission. Many Republicans, including Trump allies, accuse CISA of working with social media companies to censor conservative viewpoints on elections and health. The agency denies these claims, stating that it only helped notify platforms about misinformation but never coerced them to take action. Despite bipartisan praise from election officials for strengthening cybersecurity ahead of the 2020 and 2024 elections, CISA remains under political scrutiny.

Trump has signed an executive order to "end federal censorship" and investigate past actions, raising questions about CISA's role moving forward. A conservative policy proposal, Project 2025, suggests moving CISA to the Transportation Department and limiting its role to assessing states’ election cybersecurity rather than directly assisting them. This shift would significantly reduce CISA’s influence on election security, despite its success in helping states combat foreign interference since Russia's 2016 election meddling. Some election officials, initially skeptical of federal involvement, now acknowledge CISA’s contributions to strengthening voting systems, but the agency’s future remains uncertain under the new administration.

item.title: UK Organizations Boost Cybersecurity Budgets
item.description: UK organizations are set to increase cybersecurity budgets by an average of 31% over the next year, more than double Gartner’s 15% forecast, according to Infosecurity Europe’s 2025 Cybersecurity Trends Report. While 75% of organizations expect budget growth, experts warn that higher spending does not always translate to better cyber resilience. Investment priorities include application security, network security, cloud security, and DevSecOps, driven by the rise of SaaS and rapid software deployment. However, 47% of cybersecurity leaders struggle to engage with boards, highlighting a disconnect between technical teams and strategic decision-making. The findings come as Infosecurity Europe marks its 30th anniversary, focusing on building a safer cyber world through collaboration, innovation, and education.

item.title: Alleged Darkweb forum breach: 6,500+ NATO personnel data exposed.
item.description: !UNCONFIRMED! Older breach from mid-July, claimed by the attacker. Data includes person, UUID, Modification date, Prefix, First/Middle/Last names, Portrait (not exported), Full Name, Countries, Organization, Function, Address, Phone numbers, Emails, Institution Members, Social Media (Facebook, LinkedIn, Twitter, Instagram), Remarks, Biography, Textbox.

item.title: NATO: There was officially a Russian plot to kill European weapons chief
item.description:
A senior NATO official has confirmed that there was a Russian scheme to kill Armin Papperger, the head of German arms manufacturer Rheinmetall.

The plot, which was foiled by United States and German intelligence, was part of a series of Russian plans to assassinate defense industry executives across Europe, according to NATO Deputy Assistant Secretary-General for Innovation, Hybrid, and Cyber James Appathurai.

item.title: Australia Invests $6.4M to Shield Healthcare Sector from Cyber Threats
item.description: The Australian government has announced a $6.4 million grant to the Critical Infrastructure – Information Sharing and Analysis Centre (CI-ISAC) Australia to establish a new cyber threat information-sharing network for the healthcare sector. This initiative comes in response to the increasing number of cyberattacks on healthcare organizations in Australia, including hospitals, health funds, and clinics.

item.title: Russian disinformation campaign targeting German election exposed
item.description: On January 24, German investigative nonprofit Correctiv exposed a Russian disinformation campaign, attributed to the Russia-linked Storm-1516 threat actor, targeting Germany's February general election. Over 100 fake websites spread AI-generated false claims against politicians, including Green party candidate Robert Habeck and Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock.

item.title: Entire Georgian country population exposed in a massive data leak
item.description: On January 27, 2025, cybersecurity researcher Bob Dyachenko and the Cybernews team discovered an unprotected Elasticsearch index hosted by a Germany-based cloud service provider, containing nearly five million personal data records of Georgian citizens, including ID numbers, full names, birth dates, genders, and phone numbers. The database was taken offline shortly after the discovery, but the exposure poses significant risks for the affected individuals.

item.title: EU Sanctions Three Russians For 2020 Cyber-Attack on Estonia
item.description: Three Russian nationals have been sanctioned by the EU for their involvement in a 2020 cyber espionage operation targeting Estonian government agencies. The Council said they breached several Estonian ministries, including Economic Affairs and Communications, Social Affairs and Foreign Affairs, and stole thousands of sensitive documents containing classified information. The sanctioned individuals will have all assets in EU countries frozen and been issued with a travel ban from the region. Additionally, any EU-based individuals and entities are banned on making funds available to those listed.

item.title: Baltic Sea data cable damaged in latest case of potential sabotage
item.description:
Disruption of line between Sweden and Latvia follows earlier incidents linked to Russia and China. The ship suspected to be responsible for the potential sabotage was captured by Sweden. Latvia's navy identified a suspect vessel, the Michalis San, near the location of the cable damage, along with two other ships. Naval tracking sites showed the Michalis San was en route to Russia. Sweden said Sunday that it seized a vessel suspected of damaging a fiber-optic cable under the Baltic Sea that links the country to Latvia, in what authorities are investigating as an act of "aggravated sabotage."

European Commission President Ursula Von der Leyen reiterated her pledges to improve the security of the bloc's critical infrastructure following reports that an undersea Baltic cable had been damaged.

Reference

Reference

item.title: Cyber Attack Halts Operation of Supreme Administrative Court's in Bulgaria
item.description: A cyber attack stopped the work of the information systems of the Supreme Administrative Court (SAC) and the administrative courts, as well as the SAC website, the press centre of the SAC said.

item.title: After Bulgaria and Hungary last week, new bomb threats for schools in Slovenia and Bosnia-Hercegovina
item.description:
The HU and SI threats have many similarities. Like the email address starts with "fighter" translated to the local language, the first sentence translated to English of the email appears to be the same in both cases. No technical details are available from Bih.

Reference

item.title: China's new cheap AI competes with the Western Giants
item.description:
DeepSeek R1 is an innovative open source artificial intelligence model developed by DeepSeek, a Chinese company, which is making a sensation in the AI world. DeepSeek R1 has been praised by researchers for its ability to tackle complex reasoning tasks, particularly in mathematics and coding. The model employs a “chain of thought” approach similar to that used by ChatGPT o1, which lets it solve problems by processing queries step by step. Little is known about the lab and its founder, Liang WenFeng. DeepSeek was born of a Chinese hedge fund called High-Flyer Quant that manages about $8 billion in assets, according to media reports. Researchers claim that DeepSeek has built-in censorship.

Reference

Reference

item.title: A massive cyberattack against Slovakia is underway
item.description: Another massive cyber attack against Slovakia is currently underway, this time targeting the General Health Insurance Company (VšZP), Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico said at a press conference on Friday afternoon. He blamed Ukraine for the attack. Minister of Health Kamil Šaško added that the cyberattack continues, but so far all attempts to penetrate have been repelled. He assured the inhabitants of Slovakia that the provision of all services provided by VšZP is not threatened.

item.title: The X page of FalconFeeds.io was hacked to display Bitcoin and Ethereum adverts
item.description: Cybersecurity / threat intelligence firm FalconFeeds.io has confirmed the attack. " We are aware that our X account Falcon Feeds has been compromised despite having 2FA enabled. We are actively investigating the incident and apologize for any inconvenience caused. Please note that recent crypto-related posts are scams, and we are in no way associated with them."

item.title: Conduent confirms cybersecurity incident behind recent outage
item.description: American business services giant and government contractor Conduent confirmed today that a recent outage resulted from what it described as a "cyber security incident." Conduent has over 31,000 employees and provides services to half of Fortune 100 companies and over 600 government and transportation agencies. These include nine top U.S. health plans, four of five top global automakers, and multiple U.S. banks and pharma companies.

item.title: Bomb threats in Bulgaria
item.description: On 22th January, around a few 100 schools in Bulgaria also received bomb threats. The threats are also investigated by the Bulgarian cybercrime police.

item.title: Think-tank warns of Russian meddling in German election
item.description: On January 20, Reuters reported that the German think-tank CeMAS found that Russia is conducting a disinformation campaign on social media to influence Germany's upcoming election, aiming to boost the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party and undermine mainstream parties. The campaign, which has typical patterns of Russia's Doppelgaenger and has reached over 2.8 million views, spreads false information and has been amplified by fake accounts.

item.title: Researchers say new attack could take down the European power grid
item.description: Researchers have revealed critical vulnerabilities in Central Europe’s power grid infrastructure, which relies on unencrypted Radio Ripple Control signals to manage renewable energy facilities and streetlights. These signals, transmitted over radio frequencies, can be intercepted, recorded, and replayed by attackers to manipulate grid operations, potentially controlling up to 60 GW of power in Germany alone. The researchers demonstrated how malicious actors could theoretically exploit this system to destabilize the grid, potentially triggering widespread blackouts, though grid experts dispute the feasibility of such a catastrophic scenario. Despite this, the lack of encryption and outdated protocols like Radio Ripple Control underscore significant risks to critical infrastructure, with experts urging a transition to modern, secure alternatives such as LTE-based systems.

item.title: New GhostGPT AI Chatbot Facilitates Malware Creation and Phishing
item.description: Researchers at Abnormal Security have discovered a new malicious generative AI tool called GhostGPT, which is being sold on Telegram since late 2024. GhostGPT is designed to assist cybercriminals in executing various malicious activities, including malware creation, exploit development, and crafting convincing phishing and business email compromise (BEC) scams. Unlike prior tools such as WormGPT, WolfGPT, and EscapeGPT, GhostGPT simplifies access through a Telegram bot, eliminating the need for jailbreaking ChatGPT or configuring open-source large language models (LLMs).

item.title: Bomb threatening in 268 Hungarian schools via email
item.description:
Following the bomb threats in Slovakia and Serbia in the autumn of 2024, on 23. January 2024 around 268 Hungarian schools have received bomb threats from the email address harcos@coredp.com.

Until the afternoon of 23th no devices were found in any institutions. Schools will resume in normal operation on the morning of 24th.

item.title: US DHS dismisses Advisory Committees including the one investigating Salt Typhoon incidents
item.description: The United States’ Department of Homeland Security (DHS) under the Trump administration dismissed all Advisory Committee members, including those of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency’s (CISA) Cyber Safety Review Board (CSRB). The CSRB, tasked with reviewing major cybersecurity incidents, was actively investigating Salt Typhoon, the Chinese state-sponsored group linked to breaches in telecommunications networks. The decision, announced in a letter, was signed by acting DHS Secretary Benjamine C. Huffman and justified as a measure to avoid “misuse of resources”. The letter also stated that dismissed members could reapply for future roles in DHS committees, though no specifics were provided on which committees may be reconstituted or with whom.

item.title: Iran and Russia sign agreement to deepen military security and cyber cooperation
item.description: Iran and Russia have formalized a new agreement to strengthen ties across military, security, and technological domains. Signed last week in Moscow by Russian President Vladimir Putin and Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian, the agreement aims to elevate relations between the two heavily sanctioned nations. The two countries committed to expanding efforts to counter the use of information and communication technologies for criminal activities, agreed to exchange knowledge on managing national internet segments and to advocate for stricter global digital space controls, including imposing regulations on international tech companies. This treaty builds on prior agreements between the two nations, including a 2021 cyber cooperation pact that came into effect in August 2022. That agreement emphasized joint efforts in cybersecurity, prevention of cybercrime, and a mutual pledge not to engage in cyberattacks against one another.

item.title: New Star Blizzard spear-phishing campaign targets WhatsApp accounts
item.description: Pro-Russian cyber threat actor Star Blizzard has shifted its tactics to target WhatsApp accounts in a spear-phishing campaign focused on government officials, diplomats, defense researchers, and entities aiding Ukraine. This campaign used emails impersonating U.S. government officials, tricking recipients into scanning QR codes that granted attackers access to WhatsApp messages via account linking. Although this campaign ended in November 2024, it demonstrates Star Blizzard's adaptability, leveraging new access methods to maintain its espionage activities. Microsoft and the U.S. Department of Justice previously disrupted Star Blizzard's operations by seizing over 180 phishing-related domains, but the group rapidly adapted. Targeted victim countries include the United States, Ukraine, and others indirectly involved in Russia-Ukraine-related diplomacy and research. Enhanced security measures, including advanced anti-phishing tools and endpoint detection, are recommended to mitigate such sophisticated threats.

item.title: Cyber Threat Assessment for Denmark’s Water Sector
item.description: The Danish Center for Cybersecurity (CFCS) has published its first threat assessment on the cyber risks facing Denmark's water sector, a critical infrastructure responsible for drinking water and wastewater management. The report highlights the sector's vulnerability, citing a December 2024 cyberattack by pro-Russian activists that disrupted water supply for approximately 50 households by damaging a pipeline. CFCS warns of a very high threat level from cybercrime and moderate risks from cyber espionage, destructive attacks, and hacktivism, noting the global geopolitical situation's influence on the cyber domain. The assessment aims to help organizations in the water sector understand the threat landscape, strengthen risk management, and implement CFCS-recommended cybersecurity measures to safeguard systems and access points.

item.title: Antonescu confirmed as PSD’s presidential candidate as tensions remain high
item.description: Crin Antonescu, a member of Romania's National Liberal Party (PNL), has been confirmed as the presidential candidate for the PSD-PNL-UDMR governing alliance, despite internal opposition within the Social Democratic Party (PSD). His candidacy will be formally approved at the PSD congress on February 2. The upcoming presidential election, rescheduled after the annulment of the previous results by Romania’s Constitutional Court, is set for May 2025. Antonescu faces challenges in unifying his coalition and appealing to younger voters, as recent polls place him second with 25%, trailing Călin Georgescu at 38%. Notably, political tensions remain high, with potential rival candidates like Victor Ponta hinting at their ambitions.

item.title: US Big Tech backtracks on EU fact-checking commitments
item.description: Major tech companies, including Google, Meta, TikTok, and Microsoft, are retreating from their commitments to the EU's Code of Practice on Disinformation, raising concerns about the future of fact-checking in the region. Google and Microsoft have indicated they will no longer support fact-checking for platforms like YouTube and Bing, citing existing measures or irrelevance to their services, while Meta has signaled potential shifts toward a community notes model. TikTok remains committed for now but conditioned its compliance on similar commitments from others. Civil society groups warn this trend undermines independent fact-checking and risks amplifying misinformation. This rollback comes as the EU prepares to enforce stricter disinformation regulations under the Digital Services Act (DSA) by mid-2025.

item.title: US hits back at cyber threats with offensive operations
item.description: On January 17, Politico reported on statements by Anne Neuberger, a senior Biden administration cyber official, who disclosed that the US had carried out secret offensive cyber operations against foreign adversaries targeting critical infrastructure. These classified measures aim to disrupt malicious networks and strengthen cybersecurity. Neuberger also emphasized the administration’s initiatives to address vulnerabilities, including a recent executive order requiring secure software for federal agencies.

item.title: EU-based Trust Service Providers targeted in recent cyberattacks
item.description: In January 2025, at least three EU-based Trust Service Providers (TSPs) reported on significant cybersecurity incidents resulting in potential data breaches. All three companies operate under the eIDAS Regulation (EU 910/2014), which governs electronic identification and trust services across the EU. No connection between the three incidents have been established at the time of writing.

item.title: Spear-Phishing Campaign Targets WhatsApp Accounts in Ukraine
item.description: Pro-Russian actor Star Blizzard has launched a new spear-phishing campaign targeting government, diplomacy, defense, international relations, and Ukraine aid organizations, as reported by Microsoft Threat Intelligence. The campaign, observed in November 2024, marks a shift in Star Blizzard’s tactics following the exposure and disruption of its earlier activities. The attack involves impersonating U.S. officials in phishing emails that invite targets to join WhatsApp groups supporting Ukraine, with a broken QR code designed to elicit a response. Victims are then sent a link to a fake WhatsApp invitation page where scanning a new QR code allows attackers to link their device to the victim's WhatsApp account. Without using malware, the attackers gain access to messages and can exfiltrate data through browser plugins.

item.title: Fake news about the Slovenian Prime Minister appeared on Facebook
item.description: On Facebook, paid fake posts featuring doctored images and misleading text falsely claiming that Slovenian Prime Minister Robert Golob had been arrested by police appeared starting Wednesday. The posts, which mimicked the visual style of Slovenske novice, have since been removed, according to the government communication office. The fraudulent posts linked to an empty website registered anonymously in January 2024, suggesting an effort to discredit the government and sow instability in Slovenia.

item.title: Von der Leyen takes aim at China and signals to Trump in cautious Davos speech
item.description: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, in her speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, emphasized the need for a balanced trade relationship with China, citing concerns over state-subsidized exports that disrupt global markets and undermine competition. She criticized China's economic policies, including subsidies for electric vehicles, which the EU countered with increased tariffs. Von der Leyen also highlighted the vulnerabilities of global supply chains, warning about their potential weaponization, such as in energy dependencies and cybersecurity risks, particularly targeting critical infrastructure like undersea data cables. Addressing U.S.-Europe trade ties, she underscored mutual economic interdependence, urging collaboration to safeguard economic and national security without undermining innovation and global prosperity.

item.title: Ukrainian Hackers Attack Russian Financial Services
item.description: Pro-Ukraine hacking group Yellow Drift targeted Roseltorg, a major Russian electronic trading platform integral to public procurement, defense contracts, and construction industries, in a significant cyberattack. Claiming responsibility, Yellow Drift stated they deleted 550 terabytes of data, including emails and backups, publishing evidence of their breach online. While Roseltorg reported full restoration of its systems, the attack disrupted operations, causing delays and concerns among users, including prominent Russian corporations and government agencies. This incident is part of a broader wave of cyberattacks by pro-Ukraine groups on Russian entities, highlighting vulnerabilities in critical infrastructure and the weaponization of cyber operations in geopolitical conflicts.

item.title: British Regulator Will Investigate Google
item.description: The UK Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has launched an investigation into Google's dominant market position in search and advertising, scrutinizing its impact on consumers, publishers, businesses, and rival search engines. Key areas under review include Google's search platform, its Google Ads service, and the role of its AI assistant, Gemini. With Google accounting for 90% of UK web searches and widely utilized for advertising, the CMA aims to determine if the company stifles competition or limits user choice. If violations are found, potential remedies could include data-sharing mandates or granting publishers greater control over how their content is used in Google's AI systems, addressing concerns over the integration of proprietary material in AI technologies. This investigation mirrors global scrutiny, as Google faces similar challenges in the U.S. and beyond regarding its practices in digital markets.

item.title: US Sanctions Chinese Hackers for Treasury, Telecom Breaches (Salt Typhoon)
item.description: The U.S. has imposed sanctions on Chinese state-backed cyber actors for their involvement in high-profile cyberattacks, including the December 2024 breach of the Department of the Treasury and the November 2024 compromise of U.S. telecom providers. Sanctioned entities include Yin Kecheng, implicated in the Treasury hack via a third-party vendor, and Sichuan Juxinhe Network Technology Co., Ltd, linked to the theft of sensitive call records and communications in a telecom attack orchestrated by the Salt Typhoon group. These actions highlight escalating Chinese cyber operations targeting U.S. infrastructure. The sanctions block U.S. assets of the designated parties and restrict transactions, aiming to disrupt their activities indirectly by limiting financial and logistical operations. Additionally, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has proposed stricter cybersecurity and supply chain requirements for telecom providers to bolster national communications security. These measures reflect a broader U.S. effort to counter cyber threats and safeguard critical infrastructure.

item.title: Deputy MP wants Italian trains back on track
item.description:
Italy’s rail network is under scrutiny following incidents of suspected sabotage and significant service disruptions. Deputy Prime Minister and Infrastructure Minister Matteo Salvini announced plans to address parliament, citing "shocking episodes" reported by Italian State Railways. Among the incidents, a chain was discovered hanging from an overhead electrical system, risking severe damage to train pantographs and power lines, and an attempted break-in targeted a control unit. Rome prosecutors have launched an investigation into what appears to be deliberate interference, as reports indicate suspiciously frequent and coordinated malfunctions in critical areas.

The disruptions come amid a €100 billion railway modernization initiative, with over 1,200 active construction sites. Salvini has attributed current challenges to decades of mismanagement while defending the government's efforts to improve the rail system. However, the opposition has criticized Salvini, with former Prime Minister Matteo Renzi accusing him of mismanagement and calling for his resignation. The issue has sparked a political debate, adding pressure on Salvini as public frustration grows over the rail crisis.

item.title: Otelier data breach triggers serious data security concerns
item.description:
The hospitality industry is grappling with a significant cybersecurity incident involving Otelier, a popular data management software provider for major hotel chains such as Marriott, Hilton, and Hyatt. A breach occurred between July and October 2024, during which attackers stole over 8 terabytes of data stored in Amazon Web Services (AWS) storage buckets. The unauthorized access is suspected to have originated from compromised AWS credentials, potentially obtained through malware targeting an Otelier employee. Despite the scale of the breach, reports suggest no payment, employee, or operational data was affected.

Otelier, previously known as “MyDigitalOffice,” has temporarily suspended operations and engaged cybersecurity experts to investigate. Speculation indicates that the stolen data might include guest details, stay purposes, and contact information, which could be leveraged for phishing or identity theft. This breach underscores the critical need for robust cybersecurity measures in the hospitality sector to protect sensitive customer data and maintain trust. Recommendations include implementing strict data protection policies, employee training, network traffic monitoring, and encryption of sensitive information to mitigate future risks.

item.title: Anne Neuberger Steps Down as White House Cybersecurity Advisor: What’s Next for U.S. Cyber Defense?
item.description:
Anne Neuberger, Deputy National Security Advisor for Cyber and Emerging Technologies at the National Security Council, resigned on January 17, 2025, amidst heightened cybersecurity challenges in the U.S., particularly from China. Neuberger played a pivotal role in shaping the Biden administration's cybersecurity policies, including overseeing the U.S. Cyber Trust Mark program to improve consumer product security and guiding two significant cybersecurity executive orders. Her leadership helped address cyber threats targeting critical infrastructure such as power grids and communication networks.

President Biden reinforced the administration's cybersecurity efforts with an executive order issued on January 18, 2025. This directive focuses on bolstering software and cloud security, mandating secure development practices for providers, and enhancing safeguards for federal systems. Agencies like NIST, CISA, and the OMB will enforce these standards while introducing policies for securing open-source software. These measures aim to address vulnerabilities highlighted by recent cyberattacks, including breaches like Salt Typhoon and incidents targeting the Treasury Department. Experts, including Robert Huber of Tenable Public Sector, praised these advancements for addressing supply chain security and rebuilding trust in U.S. cybersecurity infrastructure.

Beyond immediate cybersecurity threats, the administration is integrating resilience against climate change into its broader strategy. Officials from CISA have emphasized enhancing critical infrastructure to address environmental risks alongside national defense, reflecting a holistic approach to cybersecurity as an intersectional issue. As Neuberger departs, her legacy underscores the importance of sustained leadership and adaptive measures in addressing the evolving threat landscape.

item.title: Salt Typhoon - The Chinese Telecom Hack – UPDATE
item.description:
The Salt Typhoon cyberattack, attributed to Chinese state-sponsored actors, has emerged as one of the most significant cybersecurity incidents in U.S. history, targeting major telecommunications firms like AT&T, Verizon, and T-Mobile. First disclosed in November 2024, the breach potentially compromised the cellular data of millions of Americans and highlighted the hackers' ability to maintain prolonged access to critical systems. Federal agencies, including the FBI, CISA, and NSA, alongside international partners from Australia, Canada, and New Zealand, are still investigating the attack's scope and objectives. Officials have confirmed the activity as a "persistent threat," with ongoing malicious activity and an uncertain timeline for full remediation.

The attack is part of a broader Chinese intelligence operation that has also targeted communications firms across Asia, Europe, and the MENA regions. The hack, involving advanced persistent threats (APTs) like Salt Typhoon, underscores the strategic value of telecommunications networks for espionage, destabilization, and geopolitical leverage. High-profile victims in the U.S. include presidential campaigns and Senate offices, raising national security alarms. Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas and Deputy National Security Adviser Anne Neuberger have called the breach highly sophisticated and deeply concerning.

The incident has prompted calls for improved cybersecurity practices, including roader encryption use and stricter measures for protecting critical infrastructure. Experts emphasize the need for heightened vigilance among telecom providers and governments globally, as well as stronger collaboration with private cybersecurity firms like Microsoft and Mandiant to combat evolving threats. This breach also intensifies tensions between the U.S. and China over cyber-espionage and underscores the urgent need to fortify the resilience of digital infrastructure against nation-state attacks.

item.title: Budget 2025 on the Horizon: Will India Take the Leap in Enhancing Cybersecurity and Data Privacy?
item.description:
India’s Union Budget 2025 is poised to play a transformative role in bolstering the nation’s cybersecurity framework as digital platforms and technologies become increasingly integral to business, governance, and daily life. Manish Mimani, CEO of Protectt.ai, highlights the urgency of addressing cybersecurity challenges by allocating resources for innovation, resilience, and skill development to safeguard India’s digital ecosystem. His recommendations focus on fostering innovation, enabling cost-effective security solutions, and developing a skilled cybersecurity workforce.

Key recommendations include establishing dedicated cybersecurity R&D hubs across cities to drive innovation in homegrown security technologies and reduce dependency on foreign solutions. Mimani also emphasizes financial incentives for cybersecurity startups through tax holidays, grants, and subsidized loans to stimulate growth in this critical sector. Bridging the talent gap is another priority, with calls for comprehensive upskilling programs, subsidized training, and collaboration with educational institutions to attract and nurture cybersecurity talent.

To encourage broader adoption of security practices, Mimani suggests reducing GST on Indian-made cybersecurity products and lowering import duties on essential hardware like servers and GPUs, making advanced technologies more accessible. Public-private partnerships could also accelerate the development of shared cybersecurity infrastructure, enabling threat intelligence sharing and innovation. Tax benefits for businesses implementing strong cybersecurity measures could further incentivize proactive defenses, ensuring a resilient digital economy.

By integrating these measures into Budget 2025, India can enhance its defenses, foster technological innovation, and secure its position as a global technology hub while safeguarding its rapidly expanding digital ecosystem.
